persona.persname: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster
Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

sceneref.stagedir:
ENTER KING RICHARD, IOHN
OF GAVNT, WITH OTHER
Nobles and attendants.

speech.speaker: King Richard.
speech.line: OVld Iohn of Gaunt time honoured Lancaﬅer.
Haﬅ thou according to thy oath and bande
Brought hither Henrie Herford thy bolde ſonne,
Here to make good the boiﬅrous late appeale,
Which then our leyſure would not let vs heare
Againﬅ the Duke of Norfolke, Thomas Moubray?

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: I haue my Liege.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Tell me moreouer haﬅ thou ſounded him,
If he appeale the Duke on ancient malice,
Or worthily as a good ſubieƈt ſhould
On ſome knowne ground of treacherie in him.

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: As neere as I could ﬁft him on that argument,
On ſome apparent daunger ſeene in him,
Aimde at your highnes, no inueterate malice.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Then call them to our preſence face to face,
And frowning brow to brow our ſelues will heare,
The accuſer and the accuſed freely ſpeake:
High ﬅomackt are they both and full of ire,
In rage, deafe as the ſea, haﬅie as fire.

speech.speaker: Bulling.
speech.line: Manie yeares of happie daies befall,
My gratious ſoueraigne my moﬅ louing liege.

speech.speaker: Mowb.
speech.line: Each day ﬅill better others happines,
Vntill the heauens enuying earths good hap,
Adde an immortall title to your Crowne.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: We thanke you both, yet one but flatters vs,
As well appeareth by the cauſe you come,
Namely to appeale each other of high treaſon:
Cooﬁn of Herford, what doﬅ thou obieƈt
Againﬅ the Duke of Norffolke Thomas Mowbray?

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: Firﬅ, heauen be the record to my ſpeech,
In the deuotion of a ſubieƈts loue,
Tendring the pretious ſafetie of my Prince,
And free from other misbegotten hate,
Come I appellant to this princely preſence.
Now Thomas Mowbray do I turne to thee,
And marke my greeting well: for what I ſpeake
My body ſhall make good vpon this earth,
Or my diuine ſoule anſwer it in heauen:
Thou art a traitour and a miſcreant,
Too good to be ſo, and too bad to liue,
Since the more faire and criﬅall is the skie,
The vglier ſeeme the cloudes that in it flie:
Once more, the more to aggrauate the note,
With a foule traitors name ﬅuffe I thy throte,
And wiſh (ſo pleaſe my Soueraigne) ere I moue,
What my tong ſpeaks, my right drawen ſword may proue.

speech.speaker: Mow.
speech.line: Let not my cold wordes here accuſe my zeale,
Tis not the triall of a womans warre,
The bitter clamour of two eger tongues
Can arbitrate this cauſe betwixt vs twaine,
The bloud is hote that muﬅ be coold for this,
Yet can I not of ſuch tame patience boaﬅ,
As to be huiſht, and naught at all to ſay.
Firﬅ the faire reuerence of your Highneﬀe curbs me,
From giuing reines and ſpurres to my free ſpeech,
Which elſe would poﬅ vntill it had returnd,
Theſe termes of treaſon doubled downe his throat;
Setting aﬁde his high blouds royaltie,
And let him be no kinſman to my Leige,
I do defie him, and I ſpit at him,
Call him a ﬂaunderous coward, and a villaine,
Which to maintaine, I would allow him ods,
And meete him were I tied to runne afoote,
Euen to the frozen ridges of the Alpes,
Or any other ground inhabitable,
Where euer Engliſhman durﬅ ſet his foote,
Meane time, let this defend my loyaltie,
By all my hopes moﬅ falﬂy doth he lie.

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: Pale trembling coward there I throw my gage,
Diſclaiming here the kinred of the King,
And lay aﬁde my high bloudes royaltie,
Which Feare, not Reuerence makes thee to except.
If guilty dread haue left thee ſo much ﬅrength,
As to take vp mine honours pawne, then ﬅowpe,
By that, and all the rites of Knighthoode elſe,
Will I make good againﬅ thee arme to arme,
What I haue ſpoke, or thou canﬅ worſe deuiſe.

speech.speaker: Mow.
speech.line: I take it vp, and by that ſword I ſweare,
Which gently laid my Knighthood on my ſhoulder,
Ile anſwer thee in any faire degree,
Or chiualrous deﬁgne of knightly triall:
And when I mount, aliue may I not light,
If I be traitor or vniuﬅly fight.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: What doth our couﬁn lay to Mowbraies charge?
It muﬅ be great that can inherit vs,
So much as of a thought of ill in him.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: Looke what I ſpeake, my life ſhall proue it true,
That Mowbray hath receiude eight thouſand nobles
In name of Lendings for your Highnes ſouldiours,
The which he hath detaind for lewd imployments,
Like a falſe traitour, and iniurious villaine:
Beﬁdes I ſay, and will in battle proue,
Or here, or elſewhere to the furtheﬅ Verge
That euer was ſurueyed by Engliſh eye,
That all the treaſons for theſe eighteene yeares,
Complotted and contriued in this land:
Fetch from falſe Mowbray their firﬅ head and ſpring,
Further I ſay and further will maintaine
Vpon his bad life to make all this good,
That he did plotte the Duke of Gloceﬅers death,
Suggeﬅ his ſoone beleeuing aduerſaries,
And conſequently like a taitour coward,
Slucte out his innocent ſoule through ﬅreames of bloud,
Which bloud, like ſacrificing Abels cries,
Euen from the toungleﬀe Cauernes of the earth,
To me for iuﬅice and rough chaﬅiſement:
And by the glorious worth of my deſcent,
This arme ſhall do it, or this life be ſpent.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: How high a pitch his reſolution ſoares,
Thomas of Norfolke what ſaiﬅ thou to this?

speech.speaker: Mowb.
speech.line: Oh let my ſoueraigne turne awaie his face,
And bid his eares a little while be deafe,
Till I haue tolde this ﬂaunder of his bloud,
How God and good men hate ſo foule a lier.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Mowbray impartiall are our eies and eares,
Were he my brother, nay, my kingdomes heire,
As he is but my fathers brothers ſonne,
Now by ſcepters awe I make a vowe,
Such neighbour neerenes to our ſacred bloud
Should nothing priuiledge him nor partialize
The vnﬅooping firmeneﬀe of my vpright ſoule,
He is our ſubieƈt Mowbray ſo art thou,
Free ſpeech and feareleﬀe I to thee allowe.

speech.speaker: Mowb.
speech.line: Then Bullingbrooke as lowe as to thy heart
Through the falſe paﬀage of thy throate thou lieﬅ.
Three partes of that receipte I had for Callice,
Disburﬅ I duely to his highneﬀe ſouldiers,
The other part reſerude I by conſent,
For that my ſoueraigne liege was in my debt,
Vpon remainder of a deare account:
Since laﬅ I went to France to fetch his Queene:
Now ſwallow downe that lie. For Gloceﬅers death,
I ﬂewe him not but to my owne diſgrace,
Negleƈted my ſworne duety in that caſe:
For you my noble Lord of Lancaﬅer,
The honourable father to my foe,
Once did I lay an ambuſhe for your life,
A treſpaﬀe that doth vex my grieued ſoule:
Ah but ere I laﬅ receiude the Sacrament,
I did confeﬀe it, and exaƈtly begd
Your graces pardon, and I hope I had it.
This is my fault, as for the reﬅ appeald
It iﬀues from the rancour of a villaine,
A recreant and moﬅ degenerate traitour,
Which in my ſelfe I boldly will defende,
And enterchangeably hurle downe my gage
Vpon this ouerweening traitors foote,
To proue my ſelfe a loyal Gentleman,
Euen in the beﬅ bloud chamberd in his boſome,
In haﬅe whereof moﬅ hartily I pray
Your highnes to aſsigne our triall day.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Wrath kindled gentleman be ruled by me,
Lets purge this choler without letting bloud,
This we preſcribe though no Phiﬁtion,
Deepe malice makes too deepe inciﬁon,
Forget, forgiue, conclude and be agreed,
Our doƈtors ſay, this is no month to bleede:
Good Vnckle let this ende where it begonne,
Weele calme the Duke of Norfolke, you your ſonne.

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: To be a make-peace ſhal become my age,
Throw downe (my ſonne) the Duke of Norfolkes gage.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: And Norfolke throw downe his.

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: When Harry? when obedience bids,
Obedience bids I ſhould not bid againe.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Norfolke throw downe we bid, there is no boote.

speech.speaker: Mow.
speech.line: My ſelfe I throw dread ſoueraigne at thy foote,
My life thou ſhalt commaund, but not my ſhame,
The one my duety owes, but my faire name
Deſpight of death that liues vpon my graue,
To darke diſhonours vſe thou ſhalt not haue:
I am diſgraﬅe, impeacht, and baffuld heere,
Pierﬅ to the ſoule with Slaunders venomd ſpeare,
The which no balme can cure but his heart bloud
Which breathde this poyſon.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Rage wuﬅ be withﬅoode,
Giue me his gage; Lions make Leopards tame.

speech.speaker: Mowb.
speech.line: Yea but not change his ſpots: take but my ſhame,
And I reﬁgne my gage, my deare deare Lord,
The pureﬅ treaſure mortall times afford,
Is ſpotleﬀe Reputation that away
Men are but guilded loame, or painted clay,
A iewell in a ten times bard vp cheﬅ,
Is a bold ſpirit in a loyall breaﬅ:
Mine honour is my life, both grow in one,
Take honour from me, and my life is done:
Then (deare my Leige) mine honour let me trie,
In that I liue, and for that will I die.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Cooﬁn, throw vp your gage, do you beginne.

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: O God defend my ſoule from ſuch deepe ﬁnne,
Shall I ſeeme Creﬅ-fallen in my fathers ﬁght?
Or with pale beggar-feare impeach my height,
Before this out-darde Daﬅard? ere my tong
Shall wound my honour with ſuch feeble wrong,
Or ſound ſo baſe a parlee, my teeth ſhall teare
The ﬂauiſh motiue of recanting feare,
And ſpit it bleeding in his high diſgrace,
Where Shame doth harbour euen in Mowbraies face.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: We were not borne to ſue, but to commaund,
Which ﬁnce we cannot do, to make you friends,
Be ready as your liues ſhall anſwere it,
At Couentry vpon ſaint Lamberts day,
There ſhall your ſwords and launces arbitrate
The ſwelling difference of your ſetled hate,
Since we cannot atone you, we ſhall ſee
Iuﬅice deﬁgne the Viƈtors chiualrie,
Lord Marſhal, commaund our Officers at Armes,
Be ready to direƈt theſe home allarmes.

sceneref.stagedir: Enter Iohn of Gaunt with the Ducheﬀe of Gloceﬆer.

speech.speaker: Gaunt
speech.line: Alas, the part I had in Woodﬅockes bloud,
Doth more ſollicite me than your exclaimes,
To ﬅirre againﬅ the butchers of his life,
But ﬁnce correƈtion lieth in thoſe hands,
Which made the fault that we cannot correƈt:
Put we our quarrell to the will of heauen,
Who when they ſee the houres ripe on earth,
Will raine hot vengeance on offenders heads.

speech.speaker: Ducheﬀe
speech.line: Findes brotherhood in thee no ſharper ſpurre?
Hath loue in thy old bloud no liuing fire?
Edwards ſeauen ſonnes whereof thy ſelfe art one,
Were as ſeauen viols of his ſacred bloud,
Or ſeauen faire branches ſpringing from one roote:
Some of thoſe ſeuen are dried by natures courſe,
Some of thoſe branches by the Deﬅinies cut:
But Thomas my deare Lord, my life, my Gloceﬅer,
One violl full of Edwards ſacred bloud,
One flouriſhing branch of his moﬅ royall roote
Is crakt, and all the precious liquor ſpilt,
Is hackt downe, and his ſummer leaues all faded
By Enuies hand, and Murders bloudy axe.
Ah Gaunt, his bloud was thine, that bed, that womb,
That mettall, that ſelfe mould, that faſhioned thee
Made him a man: and though thou liueﬅ and breatheﬅ,
Yet art thou ﬂaine in him, thou dooﬅ conſent
In ſome large meaſure to thy fathers death,
In that thou ſeeﬅ thy wretched brother die,
Who was the modell of thy fathers life:
Call it not patience Gaunt, it is diſpaire,
In ſuffring thus thy brother to be ﬂaughtred,
Thou ſheweﬅ the naked pathway to thy life,
Teaching ﬅerne Murder how to butcher thee:
That which in meane men we intitle Patience,
Is pale cold Cowardice in noble breaﬅs.
What ſhall I ſaie? to ſafegard thine owne life,
The beﬅ way is to venge my Gloceﬅers death.

speech.speaker: Gaunt
speech.line: Gods is the quarrell for Gods ſubﬅitute,
His deputy annointed in his ﬁght,
Hath cauſd his death, the which if wrongfully,
Let heauen reuenge, for I may neuer lift
An angry arme againﬅ his miniﬅer.

speech.speaker: Duch
speech.line: Where then may I complaine my ſelfe?

speech.speaker: Gaunt
speech.line: To God the widdowes Champion and defence.

speech.speaker: Duch
speech.line: Why then I will; farewell olde Gaunt,
Thou goeﬅ to Couentry, there to behold
Our Cooſen Hereford and fell Mowbray fight.
O ſet my husbands wronges on Herefords ſpeare,
That it may enter butchers Mowbraies breﬅ:
Or if miſfortune miﬀe the firﬅ carier,
Be Mowbraies ﬁnnes ſo heauy in his boſome
That they may breake his foming courſers backe,
And throw the rider headlong in the liﬅes,
A catiue recreant to my Cooſen Hereford,
Farewell old Gaunt, thy ſometimes brothers wife,
With her companion Griefe muﬅ end her life.

speech.speaker: Gaunt
speech.line: Siﬅer farewell, I muﬅ to Couentry,
As much good ﬅay with thee, as go with me.

speech.speaker: Duch
speech.line: Yet one word more, griefe boundeth where is fals,
Not with the emptines, hollownes, but weight:
I take my leaue before I haue begone,
For ſorrow endes not when it ſeemeth done:
Commend me to my brother Edmund Yorke,
Lo this is all: nay yet depart not ſo,
Though this be al, doe not ſo quickly go:
I ſhall remember more: Bid him; ah what?
With all good ſpeede at Plaſhie viﬁte me,
Alacke and what ſhall good olde Yorke there ſee,
But empty lodgings and vnfurniſht wals,
Vnpeopled offices, vntrodden ﬅones,
And what cheere there for welcome but my grones?
Therfore commend me, let him not come there,
To ſeeke out ſorrow that dwels euery where,
Deſolate deſolate will I hence and die:
The laﬅ leaue of thee takes my weeping eie.

sceneref.stagedir: Enter Lord Marſhall and the Duke Aumerle.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: My Lord Aumerle is Harry Herford armde?

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: Yea at all points, and longs to enter in.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: The Duke of Norfolke ſprightfully and bold,
Staies but the ſummons of the appellants trumpet.

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: Why then the Champions are prepard and ﬅay
For nothing but his maieﬅies approach.

sceneref.stagedir: The trumpets ſound and the King enters with his nobles, when they are ſet, enter the Duke of Norfolke in armes defendant.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Marſhall demaunde of yonder Champion,
The cauſe of his arriuall here in armes,
Aske him his name, and orderly proceede
To ſweare him in the iuﬅice of his cauſe.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: In Gods name and the Kings ſay who thou art,
And why thou comeﬅ thus knightly clad in armes,
Againﬅ what man thou comﬅ and what thy quarrell,
Speake truly on thy knighthoode, and thy oth,
As ſo defend the heauen and thy valour.

speech.speaker: Mow.
speech.line: My name is Thomas Mowbray Duke of Norfolke,
Who hither come ingaged by my oath,
(Which God defende a Knight ſhould violate)
Both to defend my loyalty and truth,
To God, my King, and my ſucceeding iﬀue,
Againﬅ the Duke of Herford that appeales me,
And by the grace of God, and this mine arme,
To proue him in defending of my ſelfe,
A traitour to my God, my King, and me,
And as I truely fight, defend me heauen.

sceneref.stagedir: The trumpets ſound. Enter Duke of Hereford appellant in armour.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Marſhall aske yonder Knight in armes,
Both who he is, and why he commeth hither,
Thus plated in habiliments of warre,
And formally according to our lawe,
Depoſe him in the iuﬅice of his cauſe.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: What is thy name? and wherfore comﬅ thou hither?
Before king Richard in his royall liﬅs,
Againﬅ whom comes thou? and whats thy quarrell?
Speake like a true Knight, ſo defend thee heauen.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: Harry of Herford, Lancaﬅer and Darbie
Am I, who ready here do ﬅand in Armes
To proue by Gods grace, and my bodies valour
In liﬅs, on Thomas Mowbray Duke of Norffolke,
That he is a traitour foule and dangerous,
To God of heauen, king Richard and to me:
And as I truely fight, defend me heauen.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: On paine of death, no perſon be ſo bold,
Or daring, hardy, as to touch the liﬅes,
Except the Martiall and ſuch officers
Appoynted to direƈt theſe faire deﬁgnes.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: Lord Martiall, let me kiﬀe my Souereignes hand,
And bow my knee before his Maieﬅie,
For Mowbray and my ſelfe are like two men,
That vow a long and wearie pilgrimage,
Then let vs take a ceremonious leaue,
And louing farewell of our ſeuerall friends.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: The appellant in all duety greetes your Highnes,
And craues to kiﬀe your hand, and take his leaue.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: We will deſcend and fold him in our armes,
Cooﬁn of Herford, as thy cauſe is right,
So be thy fortune in this royall fight:
Farewell my bloud, which if to day thou ſhead,
Lament we may, but not reuenge the dead.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: O let no noble eie prophane a teare
For me, if I be gorde with Mowbraies ſpeare:
As confident as is the Falcons flight
Againﬅ a bird, do I with Mowbray fight.
My louing Lord, I take my leaue of you:
Of you (my noble couﬁn) Lord Aumarle,
Not ﬁcke although I haue to do with death,
But luﬅy, yong and cheerely drawing breth:
Loe, as at Engliſh feaﬅs ſo I regreet
The daintieﬅ laﬅ, to make the end moﬅ ſweet.
Oh thou the earthly Authour of my bloud,
Whoſe youthfull ſpirite in me regenerate
Doth with a two-fold vigour lift me vp,
To reach at Viƈtory aboue my head:
Adde proofe vnto mine armour with thy prayers,
And with thy bleſsings ﬅeele my launces point,
That it may enter Mowbraies waxen cote,
And furbiſh new the name of Iohn a Gaunt,
Euen in the luﬅie hauiour of his ſonne.

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: God in thy good cauſe make thee proſperous,
Be ſwift like lightning in the execution,
And let thy blowes doubly redoubled,
Fall like amazing thunder on the caske
Of thy aduerſe pernitious enemy,
Rowze vp thy youthfull bloud, be valiant and liue.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: Mine innocence and ſaint George to thriue.

speech.speaker: Mowb.
speech.line: How euer God or Fortune caﬅ my lot,
There liues or dies true to King Richards throne,
A loyall, iuﬅ, and vpright Gentleman:
Neuer did captiue with a freer heart
Caﬅ off his chaines of bondage, and embrace
His golden vncontrould enfranchiſment,
More than my dauncing ſoule doth celebrate
This feaﬅ of battle with mine aduerſarie,
Moﬅ mighty Liege, and my companion Peeres,
Take from my mouth the wiſh of happy yeeres,
As gentle, and as iocund as to ieﬅ
Go I to fight, truth hath a quiet breﬅ.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Farewell (my Lord) ſecurely I eſpie,
Vertue with Valour couched in thine eie,
Order the triall Martiall, and beginne.

speech.speaker: Mart.
speech.line: Harry of Herford, Lancaﬅer and Darby,
Receiue thy launce, and God defend the right.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: Strong as a tower in hope I cry, Amen.

speech.speaker: Mart.
speech.line: Go beare this lance to Thomas Duke of Norfolke.

speech.speaker: Herald.
speech.line: Harry of Herford, Lancaﬅer, and Darby
Stands here, for God, his ſoueraigne, and himſelfe,
On paine to be found falſe and recreant,
To proue the Duke of Norfolke Thomas Mowbray
A traitor to God, his king, and him,
And dares him to ſet forward to the fight.

speech.speaker: Herald 2
speech.line: Here ﬅandeth Thomas Mowbray D. of Norfolk
On paine to be found falſe and recreant,
Both to defend himſelfe, and to approue
Henry of Hereford, Lancaﬅer, and Darby,
To God, his ſoueraigne, and to him diﬂoyall,
Couragiouﬂy, and with a free deﬁre,
Attending but the ﬁgnall to beginne.

speech.speaker: Mart.
speech.line: Sound trumpets, and ſet forward Combatants:
Stay, the king hath throwen his warder downe.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Let them lay by their helmets, and their ſpeares,
And both returne backe to their chaires againe.
Withdraw with vs, and let the trumpets ſound,
While we returne theſe dukes what we decree.
Draw neere and liﬅ
What with our counſell we haue done:
For that our kingdomes earth ſhould not be ſoild
With that deare bloud which it hath foﬅered:
And for our eies do hate the dire aſpeƈt
Of cruell wounds plowd vp with neighbours ſword,
And for we thinke the Egle-winged pride
Of skie-aſpiring and ambitious thoughts,
With riuall hating enuy ſet on you
To wake our peace, which in our Countries cradle
Draw the ſweet infant breath of gentle ﬂeepe,
Which ſo rouzde vp with boiﬅrous vntunde drummes,
With harſh reſounding trumpets dreadfull bray,
And grating ſhocke of harſh reſounding armes,
Might from our quiet confines fright faire Peace,
And make vs wade euen in our kinreds bloud:
Therefore we baniſh you our territories:
You couﬁn Hereford, vpon paine of life,
Til twice fiue ſummers haue enricht our fields,
Shall not regreete our faire dominions,
But treade the ﬅranger paths of baniſhment.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: Your will be done; this muﬅ my comfort be,
That Sunne that warmes you here, ſhall ſhine on me,
And thoſe his golden beames to you heere lent,
Shall point on me, and guilde my baniſhment.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Norfolke, for thee remaines a heauier doome,
Which I with ſome vnwillingneﬀe pronounce,
The ﬂie ﬂow houres ſhall not determinate
The dateleﬀe limite of thy deere exile,
The hopeleﬀe word of neuer to returne,
Breathe I againﬅ thee, vpon paine of life.

speech.speaker: Mowb.
speech.line: A heauy ſentence, my moﬅ ſoueraigne Liege,
And all vnlookt for from your Highneﬀe mouth,
A deerer merit not ſo deepe a maime,
As to be caﬅ forth in the common ayre
Haue I deſerued at your Highneﬀe hands:
The language I haue learnt theſe forty yeeres,
My natiue Engliſh now I muﬅ forgo,
And now my tongues vſe is to me, no more
Than an vnﬅringed violl or a harpe,
Or like a cunning inﬅrument caſde vp,
Or being open, put into his hands
That knowes no touch to tune the harmonie:
Within my mouth you haue engaold my tongue,
Doubly portculiﬅ with my teeth and lippes,
And dull vnfeeling barren ignorance
Is made my Gaoler to attend on me:
I am too olde to fawne vpon a nurſe,
Too far in yeeres to be a pupill now,
What is thy ſentence but ſpeechleﬀe death?
Which robbes my tongue from breathing natiue breath.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: It bootes thee not to be compaſsionate,
After our ſentence playning comes too late.

speech.speaker: Mow.
speech.line: Then thus I turne me from my countries light,
To dwel in ſolemne ſhades of endleﬀe night.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Returne againe, and take an othe with thee,
Lay on our royall ſword your baniſht hands,
Sweare by the duty that y’owe to God,
(Our part therein we baniſh with your ſelues,)
To keepe the oath that we adminiﬅer:
You neuer ſhall, ſo helpe you truth and God,
Embrace each others loue in baniſhment,
Nor neuer looke vpon each others face,
Nor neuer write, regreete, nor reconcile
This lowring tempeﬅ of your home-bred hate,
Nor neuer by aduiſed purpoſe meete,
To plot, contriue, or complot any ill,
Gainﬅ vs, our ﬅate, our ſubieƈts, or our land.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: I ſweare.

speech.speaker: Mow.
speech.line: And I, to keepe al this.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: Norffolke, ſo fare as to mine enemy:
By this time, had the King permitted vs,
One of our ſoules had wandred in the aire,
Baniſht this fraile ſepulchre of our fleſh,
As now our fleſh is baniſht from this land,
Confeﬀe thy treaſons ere thou flie the realme,
Since thou haﬅ far to go, beare not along
The clogging burthen of a guiltie ſoule.

speech.speaker: Mow.
speech.line: No Bullingbrooke, if euer I were traitour,
My name be blotted from the booke of life,
And I from heauen baniſht as from hence:
But what thou art, God, thou, and I, do know,
And al too ſoone (I feare) the King ſhall rew:
Farewell (my Leige) now no way can I ﬅray,
Saue backe to England al the worlds my way.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Vncle, euen in the glaﬀes of thine eyes,
I ſee thy grieued heart: thy ſad aſpeƈt
Hath from the number of his baniſht yeeres
Pluckt foure away, ﬁxe frozen winters ſpent,
Returne with welcome home from baniſhment.

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: How long a time lies in one little word.
Foure lagging winters and foure wanton ſpringes,
End in a word, ſuch is the breath of Kinges.

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: I thanke my liege that in regard of me,
He ſhortens foure yeares of my ſonnes exile,
But little vantage ſhall I reape thereby:
For eare the ﬁxe yeares that he hath to ſpend
Can change their moones, and bring their times about,
My oile-dried lampe, and time bewaﬅed light
Shall be extint with age and endleﬀe nightes,
My intch of taper will be burnt and done,
And blindfold Death not let me ſee my ſonne.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Why Vnckle thou haﬅ many yeares to liue.

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: But not a minute King that thou canﬅ giue,
Shorten my daies thou canﬅ with ſullen ſorrowe,
And plucke nights from me, but not lend a morrow:
Thou canﬅ helpe time to furrow me with age,
But ﬅoppe no wrinckle in his pilgrimage:
Thy word is currant with him for my death,
But dead, thy kingdome cannot buy my breath.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Thy ſonne is baniſht vpon good aduiſe,
Whereto thy tong, a party verdiƈt gaue,
Why at our iuﬅice ſeemﬅ thou then to lowre?

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: Things ſweet to taﬅe, prooue in digeﬅion ſowre.
You vrgde me as a iudge, but I had rather,
You would haue bid me argue like a father:
Oh had’t beene a ﬅranger, not my child,
To ſmooth his fault I ſhould haue beene more milde:
A partiall ﬂaunder ought I to auoide,
And in the ſentence my owne life deﬅroyed:
Alas, I lookt when ſome of you ſhould ſay,
I was too ﬅriƈt to make mine owne away:
But you gaue leaue to my vnwilling tongue,
Againﬅ my will to do my ſelfe this wrong.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Cooſen farewel, and Vnckle, bid him ſo,
Sixe yeares we baniſh him and he ſhall go.

speech.speaker: Au.
speech.line: Coﬁn farewel, what preſence muﬅ not know,
From where you doe remaine let paper ſhew.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: My Lord, no leaue take I, for I will ride
As farre as land will let me by your ﬁde.

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: Oh to what purpoſe doeﬅ thou hoard thy words,
That thou returneﬅ no greeting to thy friends?

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: I haue too few to take my leaue of you,
When the tongues office ſhould be prodigall,
To breathe the abundant dolor of the heart.

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: Thy griefe is but thy abſence for a time.

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: Ioy abſent, griefe is preſent for that time.

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: What is ﬁxe winters? they are quickly gone.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: To men in ioy, but griefe makes one hower ten.

speech.speaker: Gaun.
speech.line: Call it a trauaile that thou takﬅ for pleaſure.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: My heart willl ﬁgh when I miſcall it ſo,
Which findes it an inforced pilgrimage.

speech.speaker: Gaun.
speech.line: The ſullen paﬀage of thy weary ﬅeps,
Eﬅeeme as foyle wherein thou art to ſet,
The pretious Iewell of thy home returne.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: Nay rather euery tedious ﬅride I make,
Will but remember me what a deale of world:
I wander from the Iewels that I loue.
Muﬅ I not ſerue a long apprentiſhood,
To forreine paﬀages, and in the end,
Hauing my freedome, boaﬅ of nothing elſe,
But that I was a iourneyman to griefe.

speech.speaker: Gaun.
speech.line: All places that the eie of heauen viﬁts,
Are to a wiſeman portes and happy hauens:
Teach thy neceſsity to reaſon thus,
There is no vertue like neceſity,
Thinke not the King did baniſh thee,
But thou the King. Woe doth the heauier ﬁt,
Where it perceiues it is but faintly borne:
Go, ſay I ſent thee foorth to purchaſe honour,
And not the King exilde thee; or ſuppoſe,
Deuouring peﬅilence hangs in our aire,
And thou art flying to a freſher clime:
Looke what thy ſoule holds deare, imagine it
To ly that way thou goeﬅ, not whence thou comﬅ:
Suppoſe the ﬁnging birds muﬁtions,
The graﬀe whereon thou treadﬅ, the preſence ﬅrowd,
The flowers, faire Ladies, and thy ﬅeps, no more
Then a delightfull meaſure or a dance,
For gnarling ſorrow hath leﬀe power to bite,
The man that mocks at it, and ſets it light.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: Oh who can hold a fier in his hand,
By thinking on the froﬅy Caucaſus?
Or cloy the hungry edge of appetite,
By bare imagination of a feaﬅ?
Or wallow naked in December ſnow,
By thinking on fantasﬅicke ſommers heate?
Oh no, the apprehenﬁon of the good,
Giues but the greater feeling to the worſe:
Fell ſorrowes tooth doth neuer ranckle more,
Then when he bites, but launceth not the ſoare.

speech.speaker: Gaun.
speech.line: Come come my ſonne Ile bring thee on thy way,
Had I thy youth and cauſe, I would not ﬅay.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: Then Englands ground farewell, ſweet ſoile adiew,
My mother and my nurſe that beares me yet,
Where eare I wander boaﬅ of this I can,
Though baniﬅ, yet a true borne Engliſh man.

sceneref.stagedir: Enter the King with Buſhie, &c at one dore, and the Lord Aumarle at another.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: We did obſerue. Cooſen Aumarle,
How far brought you high Hereford on his way?

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: I brought high Herford, if you call him ſo,
But to the next high way, and there I left him.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: And ſay, what ﬅore of parting teares were ſhed?

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: Faith none for me, except the Northeaﬅ winde,
Which then blew bitterly againﬅ our faces,
Awakt the ﬂeeping rhewme, and ſo by chance
Did grace our hollow parting with a teare.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: What ſaid our couﬁn when you parted with him?

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: Farewel, & for my hart diſdained that my tongue
Should ſo prophane the word that taught me craft,
To counterfaite oppreſsion of ſuch griefe,
That words ſeemd buried in my ſorrowes graue:
Marry would the word Farewel haue lengthned howers,
And added yeares to his ſhort baniſhment,
He ſhould haue had a volume of farewels:
But ﬁnce it would not, he had none of me.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: He is our Cooſens Cooﬁn, but tis doubt,
When time ſhall call him home from baniſhment,
Whether our kinſman come to ſee his friends.
Our ſelfe and Buſhie,
Obſerued his courtſhip to the common people,
How he did ſeeme to diue into their harts,
With humble and familiar courteﬁe,
With reuerence he did throw away on ﬂaues,
Wooing poore craftſmen with the craft of ſmiles,
And patient vnder-bearing of his fortune,
As twere to baniſh their affeƈts with him,
Off goes his bonnet to an oyﬅerwench,
A brace of draimen bid God ſpeed him well,
And had the tribute of his ſupple knee,
With thankes my countreymen my louing friendes,
As were our England in reuerﬁon his,
And he our ſubieƈts next degree in hope.

speech.speaker: Greene.
speech.line: Wel, he is gone, and with him go theſe thoughts,
Now for the rebels which ﬅand out in Ireland,
Expedient mannage muﬅ be made my liege,
Ere further leyſure yeeld them further meanes,
For their aduantage and your highnes loﬀe.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: VVe will our ſelfe in perſon to this warre,
And for our coffers with too great a court,
And liberall larges are growen ſome what light,
VVe are inforﬅ to farm our royall Realme,
The reuenew whereof ſhall furniſh vs,
For our affaires in hand if that come ſhort,
Our ſubﬅitutes at home ſhall haue blanke charters,
Whereto, when they ſhal know what men are rich,
They ſhal ſubſcribe them for large ſummes of gold,
And ſend them after to ſupply our wants,
For we will make for Ireland preſently.

sceneref.speech: Buſh. Olde Iohn of Gaunt is grieuous ﬁcke my Lord, Sodainely taken, and hath ſent poﬅ haﬅe, To intreate your Maieﬅie to viﬁte him..

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Where lies he?

speech.speaker: Buſh.
speech.line: At Ely houſe.

sceneref.speech: King Now put it (God) in the Phyﬁtions mind, To help him to his graue immediatly: The lining of his coffers ſhall make coates To decke our ſouldiers for theſe Iriſh warres. Come gentlemen, lets all go viﬁte him, Pray God we may make haﬅe and come too late, Amen..

sceneref.stagedir: Enter Iohn of Gaunt ﬁcke, with the duke of Yorke, &c.

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: Wil the King come that I may breathe my laﬅ?
In holſome counſell to his vnﬅaied youth.

speech.speaker: Yorke
speech.line: Vex not your ſelfe, nor ﬅriue not with your breath,
For all in vaine comes counſell to his eare.

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: Oh but they ſay, the tongues of dying men,
Inforce attention like deepe harmony:
Where words are ſcarce they are ſeldome ſpent in vaine,
For they breathe truth that breathe their wordes in paine:
He that no more muﬅ ſay, is liﬅened more
Than they whom youth and eaſe haue taught to gloſe,
More are mens ends markt than their liues before:
The ſetting Sunne, and Muﬁcke at the cloſe,
As the laﬅ taﬅe of ſweetes is ſweeteﬅ laﬅ,
Writ in remembrance more than things long paﬅ,
Though Richard my liues counſell would not heare,
My deaths ſad tale may yet vndeafe his eare.

speech.speaker: Yorke
speech.line: No, it is ﬅopt with other flattering ſoundes,
As praiſes of whoſe taﬅe the wiſe are found
Laſciuious meeters, to whoſe venome ſound
The open eare of youth doth alwayes liﬅen.
Report of faſhions in proude Italie,
Whoſe maners ﬅill our tardy apiſh nation
Limps after in baſe imitation:
Where doth the world thruﬅ forth a vanitie,
So it be new, theres no reſpeƈt how vile,
That is not quickly buzd into his eares:
Then all too late comes Counſell to be heard,
Where will doth mutiny with wits regard:
Direƈt not him whoſe way himſelfe will chuſe.
Tis breath thou lackﬅ and that breath wilt thou looſe.

speech.speaker: Gaunt
speech.line: Me thinkes I am a prophet new inſpirde,
And thus expiring do foretell of him,
His raſh fierce blaze of ryot cannot laﬅ:
For violent fires ſoone burne out themſelues.
Small ſhoures laﬅ long, but ſodaine ﬅormes are ſhort:
He tires betimes that ſpurs too faﬅ betimes
With eagre feeding foode doth choke the feeder,
Light vanitie inſatiate cormorant,
Conſuming meanes ſoone praies vpon it ſelfe:
This royall throne of Kings, this ſceptered Ile,
This earth of maieﬅie, this ſeate of Mars,
This other Eden, demy Paradice,
This foretreﬀe built by Nature for her ſelfe,
Againﬅ infeƈtion and the hand of warre,
This happy breede of men, this little world,
This precious ﬅone ſet in the ﬁluer ſea,
Which ſerues it in the office of a wall,
Or as moate defenﬁue to a houſe,
Againﬅ the enuie of leﬀe happier lands.
This bleﬀed plot, this earth, this realme, this England,
This nurſe, this teeming wombe of royall Kings,
Feard by their breed, and famous by theyr byrth,
Renowned for theyr deedes as far from home,
For chriﬅian ſeruice, and true chiualry,
As is the ſepulchre in ﬅubborne Iewry,
Of the worlds ranſome bleﬀed Maries ſonne:
This land of ſuch deare ſoules, this deere deere land,
Deare for her reputation through the world,
Is now leaſde out; I dye pronouncing it,
Like to a tenement or pelting Farme.
England bound in with the triumphant ſea,
Whoſe rockie ſhoare beates backe the enuious ﬁege
Of watry Neptune, is now bound in with ſhame,
With inckie blots, and rotten parchment bonds:
That England that was wont to conquer others,
Hath made a ſhamefull conqueﬅ of it ſelfe:
Ah would the ſcandall vaniſh with my life,
How happy then were my enſuing death?

speech.speaker: Yorke
speech.line: The King is come, deale mildely with his youth,
For young hot colts being ragde, do rage the more.

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: How fares our noble vncle Lancaﬅer?

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: What comfort man? how iﬅ with aged Gaunt?

speech.speaker: Gaunt
speech.line: O how that name befits my compoﬁtion!
Old Gaunt indeede, and gaunt in being olde:
Within me Griefe hath kept a tedious faﬅ.
And who abﬅaines from meate that is not gaunt?
For ﬂeeping England long time haue I watcht,
Watching breedes leaneneﬀe, leaneneﬀe is all gaunt:
The pleaſure that ſome fathers feede vpon
Is my ﬅriƈt faﬅ; I meane my childrens lookes,
And therein faﬅing haﬅ thou made me gaunt:
Gaunt am I for the graue, gaunt as a graue,
Whoſe hollow wombe inherites naught but bones.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Can ﬁcke men play ſo nicely with their names?

speech.speaker: Gaunt
speech.line: No, miſery makes ſport to mocke it ſelfe,
Since thou doﬅ ſeeke to kill my name in me,
I mocke my name (great King) to flatter thee.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Should dying men flatter with thoſe that liue?

speech.speaker: Gaunt
speech.line: No no, men liuing flatter thoſe that die.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Thou now a dying ſayﬅ thou flattereﬅ me.

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: Oh no, thou dieﬅ, though I the ﬁcker be.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: I am in health, I breathe, and ſee thee ill.

speech.speaker: Gaunt.
speech.line: Now he that made me knowes I ſee thee ill,
Ill in my ſelfe to ſee, and in thee, ſeeing ill,
Thy death-bed is no leﬀer than thy land,
Wherein thou lieﬅ in reputation ﬁcke,
And thou too careleﬀe pacient as thou art
Commitﬅ thy annoynted body to the cure
Of thoſe Phyﬁtions that firﬅ wounded thee,
A thouſand flatterers ﬁt within thy Crowne,
Whoſe compaﬀe is no bigger than thy head,
And yet inraged in ſo ſmall a verge,
The waﬅe is no whit leﬀer than thy land:
Oh had thy grandﬁre with a Prophets eie,
Seene how his ſonnes ſonne ſhould deﬅroy his ſonnes,
From forth thy reach he would haue laid thy ſhame,
Depoﬁng thee before thou wert poﬀeﬅ,
Which art poﬀeﬅ now to depoſe thy ſelfe:
Why couﬁn wert thou regent of the world,
It were a ſhame to let this land by leaſe:
But for thy world enioying but this land,
Is it not more than ſhame to ſhame it ſo?
Landlord of England art thou now not, not King,
Thy ﬅate of lawe is bondﬂaue to the lawe,
And thou

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: A lunatike leane-witted foole,
Preſuming on an agues priuiledge,
Dareﬅ with thy frozen admonition
Make pale our cheeke, chaﬁng the royall bloud
With furie from his natiue reﬁdence.
Now by my ſeates right royall maieﬅie,
Wert thou not brother to great Edwards ſonne,
This tong that runnes ſo roundly in thy head,
Should runne thy head from thy vnreuerent ſhoulders.

speech.speaker: Gaunt
speech.line: Oh ſpare me not my brothers Edwards ſonne,
For that I was his father Edwards ſonne,
That bloud already like the Pellican,
Haﬅ thou tapt out and drunkenly carowﬅ,
My brother Gloceﬅer plaine well meaning ſoule,
Whom faire befall in heauen mongﬅ happy ſoules,
Maie be a preﬁdent and witnes good:
That thou reſpeƈtﬅ not ſpilling Edwards bloud:
Ioine with the preſent ﬁcknes that I haue,
And thy vnkindnes be like crooked age,
To crop at once a too long withered flower,
Liue in thy ſhame, but die not ſhame with thee,
Theſe words hereafter thy tormentors be,
Convay me to my bed then to my graue,
Loue they to liue that loue and honor haue.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: And let them die that age and ſullens haue,
For both haﬅ thou, and both become the graue.

speech.speaker: Yorke
speech.line: I doe beſeech your Maieﬅy, impute his words
To waiward ﬁcklines and age in him,
He loues you on my life, and holdes you deere,
As Harry Duke of Hereford were he here.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Right, you ſay true, as Herefords loue, ſo his
As theirs, ſo mine, and all be as it is.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: My liege, old Gaunt commends him to your Maieﬅie.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: What ſaies he?

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Nay nothing, all is ſaid:
His tongue is now a ﬅringleﬀe inﬅrument,
Words, life, and al, old Lancaﬅer hath ſpent.

speech.speaker: Yorke
speech.line: Be Yorke the next that muﬅ be bankrout ſo,
Though death be poore, it ends a mortall wo.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: The ripeﬅ fruit firﬅ fals, and ſo doth he,
His time is ſpent, our pilgrimage muﬅ be;
So much for that. Now for our Iriſh wars,
We muﬅ ſupplant thoſe rough rugheaded kerne,
Which liue like venome, where no venome elſe,
But onely they haue priuiledge to liue.
And for theſe great affaires do aske ſome charge,
Towards our aſsiﬅance we doe ſeaze to vs:
The plate, coine, reuenewes, and moueables
Whereof our Vnckle Gaunt did ﬅand poﬀeﬅ.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: How long ſhal I be patient? ah how long
Shall tender duty make me ſuffer wrong?
Not Gloceﬅers death, nor Herefords baniſhment,
Nor Gauntes rebukes, nor Englands priuate wrongs,
Nor the preuention of poore Bullingbrooke,
About his mariadge, nor my owne diſgrace,
Haue euer made me ſower my patient cheeke,
Or bende one wrinckle on my ſoueraignes face:
I am the laﬅ of noble Edwards ſonnes,
Of whom thy father Prince of Wales was firﬅ
In warre was neuer Lyon ragde more fierce,
In peace was neuer gentle lambe more milde,
Then was that young and princely Gentleman:
His face thou haﬅ, for euen ſo lookt he,
Accompliſht with a number of thy howers;
But when he frowned it was againﬅ the french,
And not againﬅ his friends: his noble hand
Did win what he did ſpende, and ſpent not that
Which his triumphant fathers hand had wonne:
His hands were guilty of no kinred bloud,
But bloudie with the enemies of his kinne:
Oh Richard. Yorke is too far gone with griefe,
Or elſe he neuer would compare betweene.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Why Vnckle whats the matter?

speech.speaker: Yorke
speech.line: Oh my liege, pardone me if you pleaſe,
If not I pleaſd not to be pardoned, am content with all,
Seeke you to ſeaze and gripe into your hands
The roialties and rights of baniſht Hereford:
Is not Gaunt dead? and doth not Hereford liue?
Was not Gaunt iuﬅ? and is not Harrie true?
Did not the one deſerue to haue an heire?
Is not his heire a well deſeruing ſonne?
Take Herfordes rightes away, and take from time
His charters, and his cuﬅomarie rightes;
Let not to morrow then enſue to daie:
Be not thy ſelfe. For how art thou a King
But by faire ſequence and ſucceſsion?
Now afore God God forbidde I ſay true,
If you doe wrongfully ſeaze Herefords rightes,
Call in the letters patents that he hath
By his attournies generall to ſue
His liuery, and deny his offred homage,
You plucke a thouſand dangers on your head,
You looſe a thouſand well diſpoſed hearts,
And pricke my tender patience to thoſe thoughts,
Which honour, and alleageance cannot thinke.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Thinke what you wil, we ceaſe into our hands
His plate, his goods, his money and his landes.

speech.speaker: Yorke
speech.line: Ile not be by the while, my liege farewell,
What will enſue hereof thers none can tell:
But by bad courſes may by vnderﬅood
That their euents can neuer fall out good.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Go Buſhie to the Earle of Wiltſhire ﬅraight,
Bid him repaire to vs to Ely houſe,
To ſee this buﬁnes: to morrow next
We will for Ireland, and tis time I trow,
And we create in abſence of our ſelfe,
Our Vnckle Yorke Lord gouernour of England;
For he is iuﬅ, and alwaies loued vs well:
Come on our Queene, to morrow muﬅ we part,
Be merry, for our time of ﬅaie is short.

sceneref.stagedir: Exeunt King and Queene: Manet North.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Well Lords, the Duke of Lancaﬅer is dead.

speech.speaker: Roﬀe
speech.line: And liuing to, for now his ſonne is Duke.

speech.speaker: Will.
speech.line: Barely in title, not in reuenewes.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Richly in both if iuﬅice had her right.

speech.speaker: Roﬀe
speech.line: My heart is great, but it muﬅ breake with ﬁlence,
Eart be disburdened with a liberall tongue.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Nay ſpeake thy mind, & let him nere ſpeake more
That ſpeakes thy words againe to doe thee harme.

speech.speaker: Wil.
speech.line: Tends that thou wouldﬅ ſpeake to the Duke of Herford?
If it be ſo, out with it boldly man,
Quicke is mine eare to heare of good towards him.

speech.speaker: Roﬀe
speech.line: No good at all that I can doe for him,
Vnleﬀe you call it good to pitty him,
Bereft, and gelded of his patrimony.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Now afore God tis ſhame ſuch wrongs are borne,
In him a royall Prince and many mo,
Of noble bloud in this declining land,
The King is not himſelfe, but baſely led
By flatterers, and what they will informe,
Meerely in hate gainﬅ any of vs all,
That will the King ſeuerely proſecute,
Gainﬅ vs, our liues, our children, and our heires.

speech.speaker: Roﬀe
speech.line: The commons hath he pild with grieuous taxes,
And quite loﬅ their hearts. The nobles hath he finde,
For ancient quarrels and quite loﬅ their hearts.

speech.speaker: Willo.
speech.line: And daily new exaƈtions are deuiſde,
As blanckes, beneuolences, and I wot not what:
But what a Gods name doth become of this?

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Wars hath not waﬅed it, for warrde he hath not,
But baſely yeelded vpon compromiſe,
That which his noble aunceﬅors atchiued with blowes,
More hath he ſpent in peace then they in wars.

speech.speaker: Roﬀe
speech.line: The Earle of Wiltſhire hath the realme in farme.

speech.speaker: Will.
speech.line: The King growen banckrout like a broken man.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Reproach and diﬀolution hangeth ouer him.

speech.speaker: Roße
speech.line: He hath not money for theſe Iriſh wars,
His burthenous taxations nothwithﬅanding,
But by the robbing of the baniſht Duke.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: His noble kinſman moﬅ degenerate King,
But Lords we heare this fearefull tempeﬅ ﬁng,
Yet ſeeke no ſhelter to auoid the ﬅorme:
We ſee the wind ﬁt ſore vpon our ſailes,
And yet we ﬅrike not, but ſecurely periſh.

speech.speaker: Roﬀe
speech.line: We ſee the very wracke that we muﬅ ſuffer,
And vnauoided is the danger now
For ſuffering ſo the cauſes of our wracke.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Not ſo, euen through the hollow eies of death,
I ſpie life peering but I dare not ſay,
How neere the tidings of our comfort is.

speech.speaker: Wil.
speech.line: Nay let vs ſhare thy thoughts as thou doﬅ ours.

speech.speaker: Roße
speech.line: Be confident to ſpeake Northumberland
We three are but thy ſelfe, and ſpeaking ſo
Thy words are but as thoughts, therefore be bold.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Then thus, I haue from le Port Blan
A Bay in Brittaine receiude intelligence,
That Harry duke of Herford, Rainold L. Cobham
That late broke from the Duke of Exeter
His brother, archbiſhop late of Canterburie,
Sir Thomas Erpingham, ﬁr Iohn Ramﬅon,
Sir Iohn Norbery, ﬁr Robert Waterton, and Francis Coines;
All theſe well furniſhed by the Duke of Brittaine
With eight tall ſhippes, three thouſand men of warre,
Are making hither with all due expedience,
And ſhortly meane to touch our Northerne ſhore:
Perhaps they had ere this but that they ﬅay
The firﬅ departing of the King for Ireland.
If then we ſhall ſhake off our ﬂauiſh yoke,
Impe out our drowping countries broken wing,
Redeeme from Broking pawne the blemiſht Crowne,
Wipe off the duﬅ that hides our Scepters guilt,
And make high Maieﬅie looke like it ſelfe,
Away with me in poﬅ to Rauenſpurgh:
But if you faint, as fearing to do ſo,
Stay, and be ſecret, and my ſelfe will go.

speech.speaker: Roße
speech.line: To horſe, to horſe, vrge doubts to them that feare.

speech.speaker: Willo.
speech.line: Holde out my horſe, and I will firﬅ be there.

speech.speaker: Buſh.
speech.line: Madam, your maieﬅie is too much ſad,
You promiﬅ, when you parted with the King,
To lay aﬁde life-harming heauines,
And entertaine a cheerefull diſpoﬁtion.

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: To pleaſe the king I did, to pleaſe my ſelfe
I cannot do it; yet I know no cauſe
Why I ſhould welcome ſuch a gueﬅ as Griefe,
Saue bidding farewell to ſo ſweete a gueﬅ,
As my ſweete Richard: yet agayne me thinkes
Some vnborne ſorrow ripe in Fortunes wombe,
Is comming towardes me and my inward ſoule,
With nothing trembles, at ſomething it grieues,
More then with parting from my Lord the King.

speech.speaker: Buſhie
speech.line: Each ſubﬅance of a griefe hath twenty ſhadowes,
Which ſhewes like griefe it ſelfe, but is not ſo:
For Sorrowes eyes glazed with blinding teares,
Diuides one thing entire to many obieƈts,
Like perſpeƈtiues, which rightly gazde vpon
Shew nothing but confuﬁon; eyde awry,
Diﬅinguiſh forme: ſo your ſweet maieﬅie,
Looking awry vpon your Lords departure,
Finde ſhapes of griefe more then himſelfe to waile,
Which lookt on as it is, is naught but ſhadows
Of what it is not; then thrice (gracious Queene)
More then your Lords departure weep not, more is not ſeen
Or if it be, tis with falſe Sorrowes eye,
Which for things true, weepes things imaginarie.

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: It may be ſo; but yet my inward ſoule
Perſwades me it is otherwiſe: how ere it be,
I cannot but be ſad: ſo heauie ſad,
As thought on thinking on no thought I thinke,
Makes me with heauy nothing faint and ſrinke.

speech.speaker: Buſh.
speech.line: Tis nothing but conceit my gratious Lady.

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: Tis nothing leﬀe: conceit is ﬅill deriude,
From ſome forefather griefe, mine is not ſo,
For nothing hath begot my ſomething griefe,
Or ſomething hath the nothing that I grieue,
Tis in reuerﬁon that I do poﬀeﬀe,
But what it is that is not yet knowen what,
I cannot name, tis nameleﬀe woe I wot.

speech.speaker: Greene
speech.line: God ſaue your maieﬅy, and well met Gentlemen,
I hope the King is not yet ſhipt for Ireland.

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: Why hopeﬅ thou ſo? tis better hope he is,
For his deﬁgnes craue haﬅe, his haﬅe good hope:
Then wherefore doﬅ thou hope he is not ſhipt?

speech.speaker: Greene
speech.line: That he our hope might haue retirde his power,
And driuen into deſpaire an enemies hope,
Who ﬅrongly hath ſet footing in this land,
The baniſht Bullingbrooke repeales himſelfe,
And with vplifted armes is ſafe ariude at Rauenſpurgh.

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: Now God in heauen forbid.

speech.speaker: Greene
speech.line: Ah Madam! tis too true, and that is worſe:
The lord Northumberland, his ſon yong H. Percie,
The lords of Roﬀe, Beaumond, and Willoughby,
With all their powerful friends are fled to him.

speech.speaker: Buſh.
speech.line: Why haue you not proclaimd Northumberland
And al the reﬅ reuolted faƈtion, traitours?

speech.speaker: Greene
speech.line: We haue, whereupon the earle of Worceﬅer
Hath broken his Staffe, reﬁgnd his Stewardſhip,
And al the houſhold ſeruants fled with him to Bullingbrook

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: So Greene, thou art the midwife to my woe,
And Bullingbrooke my ſorowes diſmall heire,
Now hath my ſoule brought forth her prodigie,
And I a gaſping new deliuered mother,
Haue woe to woe, ſorow to ſorow ioynde.

speech.speaker: Buſhie
speech.line: Diſpaire not Madam.

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: Who ſhall hinder me?
I will diſpaire and be at enmitie
With couſening Hope, he is a flatterer,
A paraﬁte, a keeper backe of Death,
Who gently would diﬀolue the bands of life,
VVhich falſe Hope lingers in extremitie.

speech.speaker: Greene
speech.line: Here comes the Duke of Yorke.

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: VVith ﬁgnes of war about his aged necke,
Oh ful of carefull buﬁnes are his lookes!
Vncle, for Gods ſake ſpeake comfortable wordes.

speech.speaker: Yorke
speech.line: Should I do ſo I ſhould bely my thoughts,
Comfort’s in heauen, and we are on the earth,
VVhere nothing liues but croﬀes, cares, and griefe:
Your husband, he is gone to ſaue far off,
VVhilﬅ others come to make him looſe at home:
Heere am I left to vnderprop his land,
Who weake with age cannot ſupport my ſelfe,
Now comes the ﬁcke houre that his ſurfet made,
Now ſhall he trie his friends that flatterd him.

speech.speaker: Seruingman
speech.line: My Lord, your ſon was gone before I came.

speech.speaker: Yorke
speech.line: He was; why ſo go all which way it will:
The nobles they are fled, the commons they are colde,
And will (I feare) reuolt on Herefords ﬁde.
Sirra, get thee to Plaſhie to my ﬁﬅer Gloceﬅer,
Bid her ſend me preſently a thouſand pound,
Hold take my ring.

speech.speaker: Seruingman
speech.line: My Lord, I had forgot to tel your Lordſhip:
To day as I came by I called there,
But I ſhall grieue you to report the reﬅ.

speech.speaker: Yorke
speech.line: What iﬅ knaue?

speech.speaker: Seruingman
speech.line: An houre before I came the Dutcheﬀe died.

speech.speaker: Yorke
speech.line: God for his mercy, what a tide of woes
Comes ruſhing on this wofull land at once!
I know not what to do: I would to God,
(So my vntruth had not prouokt him to it)
The King had cut off my head with my brothers.
What are there no Poﬅs diſpatcht for Ireland?
How ſhal we do for money for theſe wars?
Come ﬁﬅer, couﬁn I would ſay, pray pardon me:
Go fellow get thee home, prouide ſome cartes,
And bring away the armour that is there.
Gentlemen, will you go muﬅer men?
If I know how or which way to order theſe affayres
Thus diſorderly thruﬅ into my hands,
Neuer beleeue me: both are my kinſmen,
T one is my ſoueraigne, whom both my oath
And duety bids defend; tother againe
Is my kinſman, whom the King hath wrongd,
Whom conſcience, and my kinred bids to right.
Wel ſomewhat we muﬅ do: Come couﬁn,
Ile diſpoſe of you: Gentlemen, go muﬅer vp your men,
And meete me preſently at Barkly:
I ſhould to Plaſhie too, but time wil not permit:
All is vneuen, and euery thing is left at ﬁxe and ſeauen.

sceneref.stagedir: Exeunt Duke, Qu man Buſh. Greene,

speech.speaker: Buſh.
speech.line: The winde ﬁts faire for newes to go for Ireland,
But none returnes. For vs to leuie power
Proportionable to the enemy is all vnpoſsible.

speech.speaker: Gree.
speech.line: Beﬁdes our neerenes to the King in loue,
Is neare the hate of thoſe loue not the King.

speech.speaker: Bag.
speech.line: And that is the wauering commons, for their loue
Lies in their purſes, and who ſo empties them,
By ſo much fils their hearts with deadly hate.

speech.speaker: Buſh.
speech.line: Wherein the King ﬅands generally condemnd.

speech.speaker: Bag.
speech.line: If iudgement lie in them, then ſo do we,
Becauſe we euer haue beene neere the King.

speech.speaker: Gree.
speech.line: Well I will for refuge ﬅraight to Briﬅ. Caﬅle.
The Earle of Wiltſhire is already there.

speech.speaker: Buſh.
speech.line: Thither will I with you, for little office
Will the hatefull commons perfourme for vs,
Except like curs to teare vs all to pieces:
Will you go along with vs?

speech.speaker: Bag.
speech.line: No, I will to Ireland to his Maieﬅy,
Farewell if hearts preſages be not vaine,
We three here part that nere ſhall meete againe.

speech.speaker: Buſh.
speech.line: Thats as Yorke thriues to beat backe Bullingbrook.

speech.speaker: Gree.
speech.line: Alas poore Duke the taske he vndertakes,
Is numbring ſands, and drinking Oceans drie,
Where one on his ﬁde fights, thouſands will flie:
Farewell at once, for once, for all, and euer.

speech.speaker: Buſh.
speech.line: Well, we may meete againe.

speech.speaker: Bag.
speech.line: I feare me neuer.

speech.speaker: Bull
speech.line: How far is it my Lord to Barckly now?

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Beleeue me noble Lord,
I am a ﬅranger here in Gloceﬅerſhire,
Theſe high wild hils and rough vneuen waies,
Drawes out our miles and makes them weariſome,
And yet your faire diſcourſe hath beene as ſugar,
Making the hard way ſweete and deleƈtable,
But I bethinke me what a weary way
From Rauenſpurgh to Cotſhall will be found,
In Roﬀe and Willoughby wanting your company,
Which I proteﬅ hath very much beguild,
The tediouſneﬀe and proceﬀe of my trauell:
But theirs is ſweetned with the hope to haue
The preſent benefit which I poﬀeﬀe,
And hope to ioy is little leﬀe in ioye,
Then hope enioyed: by this the weary Lords
Shall make their way ſeeme ſhort as mine hath done,
By ﬁght of what I haue, your noble company.

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: Of much leﬀe value is my company,
Then your good wordes. But who comes here?

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: It is my ſonne young Harry Perſy,
Sent from my brother Worceﬅer whenceſoeuer.
Harry, how fares your Vnckle?

speech.speaker: H. Per.
speech.line: I had thought my Lord to haue learned his health of you.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Why is he not with the Queene?

speech.speaker: H. Per.
speech.line: No my good Lord, he hath forſooke the court,
Broken his ﬅaffe of office and diſperﬅ
The houſhold of the King.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: What was his reaſon, he was not ſo reſolude,
When laﬅ we ſpake together?

speech.speaker: H. Per.
speech.line: Becauſe your Lo: was proclaimed traitor,
But he my Lo: is gone to Rauenſpurgh,
To offer ſeruice to the Duke of Hereford,
And ſent me ouer by Barckly to diſcouer,
What power the Duke of Yorke had leuied there,
Then with direƈtions to repaire to Rauenſpurgh.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Haue you forgot the Duke of Herefords boy?

speech.speaker: H. Per.
speech.line: No my good Lo: for that is not forgot
Which nere I did remember, to my knowledge
I neuer in my life did looke on him.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Then learne to know him now, this is the Duke.

speech.speaker: H. Per.
speech.line: My gratious Lo: I tender you my ſeruice,
Such as it is, being tender, raw, and young,
Which elder daies ſhal ripen and confirme
To more approued ſeruice and deſert.

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: I thanke thee gentle Perſy, and be ſure,
I count my ſelfe in nothing elſe ſo happy,
As in a ſoule remembring my good friends,
And as my fortune ripens with thy loue,
It ſhalbe ﬅill thy true loues recompence,
My heart this couenant makes, my hand thus ſeales it.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: How farre is it to Barckly, and what ﬅur
Keepes good old Yorke there with his men of war?

speech.speaker: H. Per.
speech.line: There ﬅands the Caﬅle by yon tuft of trees,
Mand with 300. men as I haue heard,
And in it are the Lords of Yorke Barkly and Seymer,
None elſe of name and noble eﬅimate.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Here come the Lords of Roﬀe and Willoughby,
Bloudy with ſpurring, fiery red with haﬅe.

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: VVelcome my Lords, I wot your loue purſues,
A baniſht traitor: all my treaſury
Is yet but vnfelt thanks, which more inricht,
Shalbe your loue and labours recompence.

speech.speaker: Roße
speech.line: Your preſence makes vs rich, moﬅ noble Lord.

speech.speaker: Wil.
speech.line: And far ſurmounts our labour to attaine it.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: Euermore thanke’s the exchequer of the poore,
VVhich till my infant fortune comes to yeares,
Stands for my bounty: but who comes here?

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: It is my Lord of Barkly as I guﬀe.

speech.speaker: Barkly
speech.line: My Lord of Hereford my meﬀage is to you.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: My Lord my anſwere is to Lancaﬆter,
And I am come to ſeeke that name in England,
And I muﬅ find that title in your tongue,
Before I make reply to ought you ſay.

speech.speaker: Bar.
speech.line: Miﬅake me not my Lord, tis not my meaning,
To race one title of your honor out:
To you my Lo: I come, what Lo: you will,
From the moﬅ gratious regent of this land
The Duke of Yorke: to know what prickes you on,
To take aduantage of the abſent time,
And fright our natiue peace with ſelfeborne armes?

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: I ſhall not need tranſport my words by you,
Here comes his grace in perſon, my noble Vnckle.

speech.speaker: Yorke
speech.line: Shew me thy humble heart, and not thy knee,
Whoſe duety is deceiueable and falſe.

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: My gratious Vnckle.

speech.speaker: Yor.
speech.line: Tut tut, grace me no grace, nor vnckle me no vnckle,
I am no traitors Vnckle, and that word Grace
In an vngratious mouth is but prophane:
Why haue thoſe baniſht and forbidden legs,
Dard once to touch a duﬅ of Englands ground:
But then more why? why haue they dard to march
So many miles vpon her peacefull boſome,
Frighting her pale fac’t villadges with warre,
And oﬅentation of deſpiſed armes?
Comﬅ thou becauſe the annointed king is hence?
Why fooliſh boy the King is left behinde,
And in my loiall boſome lies his power,
Were I but now Lord of ſuch hot youth,
As when braue Gaunt thy father and my ſelfe,
Reſcued the blacke prince that young Mars of men,
From forth the ranckes of many thouſand french,
O then how quickly ſhould this arme of mine,
Now priſoner to the Palﬁe chaﬅiſe thee,
And miniﬅer correƈtion to thy fault!

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: My gratious Vnckle let me know my fault,
On what condition ﬅands it and wherein?

speech.speaker: Yorke
speech.line: Euen in condition of the worﬅ degree,
In groﬀe rebellion and deteﬅed treaſon,
Thou art a baniſht man and here art come,
Before the expiration of thy time,
In brauing armes againﬅ thy ſoueraigne.

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: As I was baniſht, I was baniſht Hereford,
But as I come, I come for Lancaﬅer.
And noble Vnckle I beſeech your grace,
Looke on my wrongs with an indifferent eie:
You are my father, for me thinkes in you
I ſee old Gaunt aliue. Oh then my father,
Will you permit that I ſhall ﬅand condemnd
A wandering vagabond, my rights and royalties
Pluckt from my armes perforce, and giuen away
To vpﬅart vnthrifts? wherefore was I borne?
If that my couﬁn King be King in England,
It muﬅ be granted I am duke of Lancaﬅer:
You haue a ſonne, Aumerle, my noble couﬁn,
Had you firﬅ died, and he bin thus trod downe,
He ſhould haue found his vncle Gaunt a father,
To rowze his wrongs and chaſe them to the baie.
I am denyed to ſue my Liuery here,
And yet my letters pattents giue me leaue.
My fathers goods are all diﬅrainde and ſold,
And theſe, and all, are all amiﬀe employed.
What would you haue me do? I am a ſubieƈt;
And I challenge law, Atturnies are denied me,
And therefore perſonally I lay my claime
To my inheritance of free deſcent.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: The noble Duke hath bin too much abuſed.

speech.speaker: Roße
speech.line: It ﬅands your Grace vpon to do him right.

speech.speaker: Willo.
speech.line: Baſe men by his endowments are made great.

speech.speaker: Yorke
speech.line: My Lords of England, let me tell you this:
I haue had feeling of my couﬁns wrongs,
And labourd all I could to do him right:
But in this kind to come, in brauing armes
Be his owne caruer, and cut out his way,
To finde out right wyth wrong it may not be:
And you that do abette him in this kinde,
Cheriſh rebellion, and are rebells all.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: The noble Duke hath ſworne his comming is,
But for his owne; and for the right of that,
We al haue ﬅrongly ſworne to giue him ayde:
And let him neuer ſee ioy that breakes that oath.

speech.speaker: Yorke
speech.line: Wel wel, I ſee the iﬀue of theſe armes,
I cannot mend it I muﬅ needes confeﬀe,
Becauſe my power is weake and all ill left:
But if I could, by him that gaue me life,
I would attach you all, and make you ﬅoope
Vnto the ſoueraigne mercie of the king;
But ﬁnce I cannot, be it knowen vnto you,
I do remaine as newter, ſo fare you well,
Vnleﬀe you pleaſe to enter in the caﬅle,
And there repoſe you for this night.

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: An offer vncle that we will accept,
But we muﬅ winne your Grace to go with vs,
To Briﬅow caﬅle, which they ſay is held
By Buſhie, Bagot, and their complices,
The caterpillers of the commonwealth,
Which I haue ſworne to weede and plucke away.

speech.speaker: Yorke
speech.line: It may be I will go with you, but yet Ile pawſe,
For I am loath to breake our countries lawes,
Nor friends, nor foes to me welcome you are:
Things paﬅ redreﬀe, are now with me paﬅ care.

sceneref.stagedir: Enter erle of Salisbury and a Welch captaine.

speech.speaker: Welch.
speech.line: My lord of Salisbury, we haue ﬅayed ten dayes,
And hardly kept our countrymen together,
And yet we heare no tidings from the King,
Therefore we will diſperſe our ſelues, farewell.

speech.speaker: Saliſ.
speech.line: Stay yet an other day, thou truﬅie Welchman,
The King repoſeth all his confidence in thee.

speech.speaker: Welch.
speech.line: Tis thought the King is dead; we wil not ﬅay,
The bay trees in our country are al witherd,
And Meteors fright the fixed ﬅarres of heauen,
The pale-facde moone lookes bloudie on the earth,
And leane-lookt prophets whiſper fearefull change,
Rich men looke ſad, and ruffians daunce and leape,
The one in feare to looſe what they enioy,
The other to enioy by rage and warre:
Theſe ﬁgnes forerunne the death or fall of Kings.
Farewell, our countrymen are gone and fled,
As well aﬀured Richard their King is dead.

speech.speaker: Saliſ.
speech.line: Ah Richard! with the eies of heauy mind
I ſee thy glory like a ſhooting ﬅarre
Fall to the baſe earth from the firmament,
Thy ſunne ſets weeping in the lowly weﬅ,
Witneſsing ﬅormes to come, wo, and vnreﬅ,
Thy friends are fled to wait vpon thy foes,
And croﬂy to thy good all fortune goes.

sceneref.stagedir: Enter Duke of Hereford, Yorke, Northumberland, Buſhie and Greene priſoners.

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: Bring forth theſe men.
Buſhie and Greene, I will not vex your ſoules,
Since preſently your ſoules muﬅ part your bodies
With too much vrging your pernitious liues,
For twere no charitie; yet to waſh your bloud
From off my hands, heere in the view of men
I will vnfold ſome cauſes of your deaths:
You haue miﬂed a Prince, a royall King,
A happy Gentleman in bloud and lineaments,
By you vnhappied, and disfigured cleane,
You haue in manner with your ﬁnfull houres
Made a diuorce betwixt his Queene and him,
Broke the poﬀeſsion of a royall bed,
And ﬅainde the beutie of a faire Queenes cheekes
With teares, drawen from her eies with your fowle wrongs,
My ſelfe a Prince, by fortune of my birth,
Neere to the King in bloud, and neere in loue,
Till you did make him miﬁnterpret me,
Haue ﬅoopt my necke vnder your iniuries,
And ﬁgh’t my Engliſh breath in forren cloudes,
Eating the bitter bread of baniſhment,
Whilﬅ you haue fed vpon my ſegniories,
Diſparkt my parkes, and felld my forreﬅ woods,
From my owne windowes torne my houſhold coate,
Rac’t out my impreeſe, leauing me no ﬁgne,
Saue mens opinions, and my liuing bloud,
To ſhew the world I am a gentleman.
This and much more, much more then twice all this
Condemns you to the death: ſee them deliuered ouer
To execution and the hand of death.

speech.speaker: Buſh.
speech.line: More welcome is the ﬅroke of death to me,
Than Bullingbrooke to England, Lords farewell.

speech.speaker: Greene
speech.line: My comfort is, that heauen will take our ſoules,
And plague iniuﬅice with the paines of hell.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: My Lord Northumberland, ſee them diſpatcht:
Vncle, you ſay the Queene is at your houſe,
For Gods ſake fairely let her be intreated,
Tel her I ſend to her my kinde commends;
Take ſpecial care my greetings be deliuered.

speech.speaker: Yorke
speech.line: A gentleman of mine I haue diſpatcht,
With letters of your loue to her at large.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: Thankes (gentle vncle:) Come Lords, away,
To fight with Glendor and his complices,
A while to worke, and after holiday.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Barkloughly caﬅle call they this at hand?

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: Yea my Lord, How brookes your Grace the ayre
After your late toſsing on the breaking ſeas?

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Needes muﬅ I like it well, I weepe for ioy,
To ﬅand vpon my kingdome once againe:
Deere earth I do ſalute thee with my hand,
Though rebels wound thee with their horſes hoofes:
As a long parted mother with her childe
Playes fondly with her teares and ſmiles in meeting;
So weeping, ſmiling greete I thee my earth,
And do thee fauours with my royall hands;
Feede not thy Soueraignes foe, my gentle earth,
Nor with thy ſweetes comfort his rauenous ſence,
But let thy Spiders that ſucke vp thy venome,
And heauy-gated toades lie in theyr way,
Doing annoyance to the treacherous feete,
Which with vſurping ﬅeps do trample thee,
Yeelde ﬅinging nettles to mine enemies:
And when they from thy boſome plucke a flower,
Guard it I pray thee with a lurking Adder,
Whoſe double tongue may wyth a mortall touch,
Throwe death vpon thy ſoueraignes enemies,
Mocke not my ſenceles coniuration Lords,
This earth ſhall haue a feeling, and theſe ﬅones,
Proue armed ſouldiers ere her natiue King,
Shall faulter vnder foule rebellions armes.

speech.speaker: Carl.
speech.line: Feare not my Lord, that power that made you king,
Hath power to keepe you king in ſpight of all,
The meanes that heauens yeeld muﬅ be imbrac’t
And not negleƈted. Elſe heauen would,
And we will not, heauens offer, we refuſe,
The profered meanes of ſuccors and redreﬀe.

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: He meanes my Lo: that we are too remiﬀe,
Whilﬅ Bullingbrooke through our ſecurity,
Growes ﬅrong and great in ſubﬅance and in power.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Diſcomfortable Cooſen knowﬅ thou not,
That when the ſearching eie of heauen is hid,
Behinde the globe that lights the lower world,
Then theeues and robbers range abroad vnſeene,
In murthers and in outrage bouldy here,
But when from vnder this terreﬅriall ball,
He fires the proud tops of the eaﬅerne pines,
And dartes his light through euery guilty hole,
Then murthers, treaſons and deteﬅed ﬁnnes,
The cloake of night being pluckt from off their backs,
Stand bare and naked trembling at themſelues?
So when this thiefe, this traitor Bullingbrooke,
Who all this while hath reueld in the night,
VVhilﬅ we were wandring with the Antipodes,
Shall ſee vs riﬁng in our throne the eaﬅ,
His treaſons will ﬁt bluſhing in his face,
Not able to endure the ﬁght of day,
But ſelfe affrighted tremble at his ﬁnne,
Not all the water in the rough rude ſea,
Can waſh the balme off from an annointed King,
The breath of worldly men cannot depoſe,
The deputy eleƈted by the Lord,
For euery man that Bullingbrooke hath preﬅ,
To lifte ſhrewd ﬅeele againﬅ our golden crowne,
God for his Ric: hath in heauenly pay,
A glorious Angell; then if Angels fight,
Weake men muﬅ fall, for heauen ﬅill gardes the right.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Welcome my Lo: how far off lies your power?

speech.speaker: Saliſ.
speech.line: Nor neare nor farther off my gratious Lo:
Than this weake arme; diſcomfort guides my tongue,
And bids me ſpeake of nothing but Deſpaire,
One day too late I feare me noble Lo:
Hath clouded all thy happy daies on earth:
O call backe yeﬅerday, bid Time returne,
And thou ſhalt haue twelue thouſand fighting men,
To day to day vnhappie daie too late,
Ouerthrowes thy ioies friends, fortune and thy ﬅate,
For all the Welſhmen hearing thou wert dead,
Are gone to Bullingbrooke diſperﬅ and fled.

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: Comfort my liege, why lookes your grace ſo pale.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: But now the bloud of 20000. men,
Did triumph in my face, and they are fled:
And till ſo much bloud thither come againe,
Haue I not reaſon to looke pale and dead?
All ſoules that wilbe ſafe, flie from my ﬁde,
For time hath ſet a blot vpon my pride.

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: Comfort my liege remember who you are.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: I had forgot my ſelfe, am I not King?
Awake thou coward, Maieﬅy thou ﬂeepeﬅ,
Is not the Kings name twenty thouſand names?
Arme arme, my name a puny ſuieƈt ﬅrikes,
At thy great glorie, looke not to the ground,
Ye fauorites of a King, are we not high?
High be our thoughts, I know my Vnckle Yorke,
Hath power enough to ſerue our turne: but who comes here?

speech.speaker: Scro.
speech.line: More health and happines betide my liege,
Then can my care tunde tongue deliuer him.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Mine eare is open, and my hart prepard,
The worﬅ is worldly loﬀe thou canﬅ vnfold,
Say, is my kingdome loﬅ? why twas my care,
And what loﬀe is it to be rid of care?
Striues Bullingbrooke to be as great as we,
Greater he ſhall not be, if he ſerue God,
Weele ſerue him to, and be his fellow ſo:
Reuolt our ſubieƈts, that we cannot mende,
They breake their faith to God as well as vs:
Crie woe deﬅruƈtion, ruine, and decay,
The worﬅ is death, and death will haue his day.

speech.speaker: Scro.
speech.line: Glad am I, that your highnes is ſo armde,
To beare the tidings of calamity,
Like an vnſeaſonable ﬅormie day,
Which makes the ﬁuer riuers drowne their ſhores,
As if the world were all diﬀolude to teares:
So high aboue his limits ſwels the rage
Of Bullingbrooke couering your fearefull land,
With hard bright ﬅeele, and harts harder then ﬅeele,
White beards haue armd their thin and haireles ſcalpes
Againﬅ thy maieﬅy: boies with womens voices,
Striue to ſpeake big and clap their femal ioints,
In ﬅiffe vnweildy armes againﬅ thy crowne,
Thy very beadſmen learne to bend their bowes,
Of double fatall ewe againﬅ thy ﬅate.
Yea diﬅaffe women mannage ruﬅie bils
Againﬅ thy ſeate both young and old rebell,
And all goes worſe then I haue power to tell.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Too well too well thou telﬅ a tale ſo ill,
Where is the Earle of Wiltſhire? where is Bagot?
What is become of Buſhie? where is Greene?
That they haue let the dangerous enemy,
Meaſure our confines with ſuch peacefull ﬅeps,
If we preuaile, their heads ſhall pay for it:
I warrant they haue made peace with Bulling.

speech.speaker: Scro.
speech.line: Peace haue they made with him indeed my Lord.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Oh villaines, vipers, damnd without redemption,
Dogs eaﬁly woon to fawne on any man.
Snakes in my hart bloud warmd, that ﬅing my hart,
Three Iudaﬀes, each one thriſe worſe then Iudas,
Would they make peace? terrible hel,
Make war vpon their ſpotted ſoules for this.

speech.speaker: Scro.
speech.line: Sweet loue I ſee changing his property,
Turnes to the ſowreﬅ and moﬅ deadly hate,
Againe, vncurſe their ſoules, their peace is made
With heads and not with hands, thoſe whom you curſe
Haue felt the worﬅ of deathes deﬅroying wound,
And lie full low grau’d in the hollow ground.

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: Is Buſhie, Greene, and the Earle of Wiltſhire dead.

speech.speaker: Scro.
speech.line: I all of them at Briﬅow loﬅ their heads.

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: Where is the Duke my father with his power?

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: No matter where, of comfort no man ſpeake:
Lets talke of graues, of wormes, and Epitaphs,
Make duﬅ our paper, and with rainy eies,
Write ſorrow on the boſome of the earth.
Lets chooſe executors and talke of wils:
And yet not ſo, for what can we bequeath,
Saue our depoſed bodies to the ground?
Our landes, our liues, and all are Bullingbrookes,
And nothing can we call our owne, but death:
And that ſmall modle of the barren earth,
Which ſerues as paﬅe, and couer to our bones,
For Gods ſake let vs ﬁt vpon the ground,
And tell ſad ﬅories of the death of Kings,
How ſome haue beene depoſd, ſome ﬂaine in warre,
Some haunted by the ghoﬅs they haue depoſed,
Some poiſoned by their wiues, ſome ﬂeeping kild;
All murthered, for within the hollow crowne
That roundes the mortall temples of a king,
Keepes death his court, and there the antique ﬁts,
Scofing his ﬅate and grinning at his pompe,
Allowing him a breath, a little ſceane,
To monarchiſe, be feard, and kil with lookes,
Infuﬁng him with ſelfe and vaine conceit,
As if this fleſh which wals about our life,
Were braﬀe impregnable: and humord thus,
Comes at the laﬅ, and with a little pin
Boares thorough his Caﬅle wall, and farewell King;
Couer your heades, and mocke not fleſh and bloud,
With ſolemne reuerence, throw a way reſpeƈt,
Tradition, forme, and ceremonious duetie,
For you haue but miﬅooke me al this while:
I liue with bread like you, feele want,
Taﬅe griefe, neede friends, ſubieƈted thus,
How can you ſay to me, I am a King?

speech.speaker: Carleil
speech.line: My lord, wiſemen nere ﬁt and waile theyr woes,
But preſently preuent the wayes to waile,
To feare the foe, ﬁnce feare oppreﬀeth ﬅrength,
Giues in your weakenes ﬅrength vnto your foe,
And ſo your follies fight againﬅ your ſelfe:
Feare and be ﬂaine, no worſe can come to fight,
And fight and die, is death deﬅroying death,
Where fearing dying, paies death ſeruile breath.

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: My father hath a power, inquire of him,
And learne to make a body of a limme.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Thou chidﬅ me well, prowd Bullingbrooke, I come
To change blowes with thee for our day of doome:
This agew fit of feare is ouerblowne,
An eaﬁe taske it is to winne our owne.
Say Scroope, where lies our vncle with his power?
Speake ſweetely man although thy lookes be ſower.

speech.speaker: Scroope.
speech.line: Men iudge by the complexion of the skie,
The ﬅate and inclination of the day;
So may you by my dull and heauy eie:
My tongue hath but a heauier tale to ſay,
I play the torturer by ſmall and ſmall
To lengthen out the worﬅ that muﬅ be ſpoken:
Your vncle Yorke is ioynd with Bullingbrooke,
And all your Northerne caﬅles yeelded vp,
And all your Southerne Gentlemen in armes
Vpon his partie.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Thou haﬅ ſaid enough:
Beſhrew thee couﬁn which didﬅ leade me foorth
Of that ſweete way I was in to diſpaire.
What ſay you now? what comfort haue we now?
By heauen Ile hate him euerlaﬅingly,
That bids me be of comfort any more.
Go to Flint Caﬅle, there Ile pine away,
A King woes ﬂaue ſhall kingly woe obey:
That power I haue, diſcharge, and let them goe
To eare the land that hath ſome hope to grow,
For I haue none, let no man ſpeake againe,
To alter this, for counſell is but vaine.

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: My Liege, one word.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: He does me double wrong,
That wounds me with the flatteries of his tong,
Diſcharge my followers, let them hence away,
From Richards night, to Bullingbrookes faire day.

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: So that by this intelligence we learne
The Welch men are diſperﬅ, and Salisburie
Is gone to meete the King, who lately landed
With ſome few priuate friends vpon this coaﬅ.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: The newes is very faire and good my lord,
Richard not farre from hence hath hid his head.

speech.speaker: Yorke
speech.line: It would beſeeme the Lord Northumberland
To ſay King Richard; alacke the heauy day,
When ſuch a ſacred King ſhould hide his head.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Your Grace miﬅakes; onely to be briefe
Left I his title out.

speech.speaker: Yorke
speech.line: The time hath bin, would you haue beene ſo briefe with him,
He would haue bin ſo briefe to ſhorten you,
For taking ſo the head, your whole heads length:

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: Miﬅake not (vncle) further then you ſhould.

speech.speaker: Yorke
speech.line: Take not (good couﬁn) further then you ſhould,
Leﬅ you miﬅake the heauens are ouer our heads.

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: I know it vncle, and oppoſe not my ſelfe,
Againﬅ their will. But, who comes here?
Welcome Harry; what, will not this caﬅle yeelde?

speech.speaker: H. Per.
speech.line: The Caﬅle royally is mand my Lord.
Againﬅ thy entrance.

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: Royally, why it containes no King.

speech.speaker: H. Per.
speech.line: Yes (my good Lord,)
It doth containe a King, King Richard lies
Within the limites of yon lime and ﬅone,
And with him are the Lord Aumerle, Lord Salisbury,
Sir Stephen Scroope, beﬁdes a cleargie man
Of holy reuerence, who I cannot learne.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Oh belike it is the biſhop of Carleil.

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: Noble Lords,
Go to the rude ribbes of that ancient Caﬅle,
Through brazen trumpet ſend the breath of parlee
Into his ruinde eares, and thus deliuer.
H. Bull. on both his knees doth kiﬀe king Richards hand,
And ſends alleageance and true faith of heart
To his moﬅ royall perſon: hither come
Euen at his feete to lay my armes and power:
Prouided, that my baniſhment repeald,
And lands reﬅored againe be freely granted;
If not, Ile vſe the aduantage of my power,
