And lay the ſummers duﬅ with ſhowres of bloud,
Rainde from the wounds of ﬂaughtered Engliſh men,
The which, how farre off from the minde of Bulling.
It is, ſuch crimſon tempeﬅ ſhould bedrench
The freſh greene lap of faire King Richards land:
My ﬅooping duety tenderly ſhall ſhew:
Go ﬁgnifie as much while here we march
Vpon the graſsie carpet of this plaine;
Lets march without the noyſe of threatning drumme,
That from this Caﬅels tottered battlements
Our faire appointments may be well peruſde.
Me thinkes King Richard and my ſelfe ſhould meete
With no leﬀe terrour than the elements
Of fire and water, when their thundring ſhocke
At meeting teares the cloudie cheekes of heauen.
Be he the fire, Ile be the yeelding water;
The rage be his, whilﬅ on the earth I raigne.
My water’s on the earth, and not on him,
March on, and marke King Richard how he lookes

sceneref.stagedir: The trumpets ſound, Richard appeareth on the walls.

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: See ſee King Richard doth himſelfe appeare
As doth the bluſhing diſcontented Sunne,
From out the fierie portall of the Eaﬅ,
When he perceiues the enuious cloudes are bent
To dimme his glorie, and to ﬅaine the tracke
Of his bright paﬀage to the Occident.

speech.speaker: Yorke
speech.line: Yet lookes he like a King, beholde his eye,
As bright as is the Eagles, lightens forth
Controlling maieﬅie; alacke alacke for woe,
That any harme ſhould ﬅaine ſo faire a ſhew.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: We are amazde, and thus long haue we ﬅoode,
To watch the feareful bending of thy knee,
Becauſe we thought our ſelfe thy lawful King:
And if wee be, howe dare thy ioynts forget
To pay their awefull duety to our preſence?
If we be not, ſhew vs the hand of God
That hath diſmiﬅ vs from our Stewardſhip;
For well we know no hand of bloud and bone
Can gripe the ſacred handle of our Scepter,
Vnleﬀe he do prophane, ﬅeale, or vſurpe,
And though you thinke that all as you haue done
Haue torne their ſoules, by turning them from vs,
And we are barren and bereft of friends:
Yet know, my maiﬅer God omnipotent,
Is muﬅering in his cloudes on our behalfe,
Armies of peﬅilence, and they ſhall ﬅrike
Your children yet vnborne, and vnbegot,
That lift your vaﬀaile hands againﬅ my head,
And threat the glorie of my precious crowne.
Tell Bullingbrooke, for yon me thinkes he ﬅandes,
That euery ﬅride he makes vpon my land,
Is dangerous treaſon: he is come to open
The purple teﬅament of bleeding warre:
But ere the crowne he lookes for, liue in peace,
Ten thouſand bloudy crownes of mothers ſonnes,
Shall ill become the flower of Englands face,
Change the complexion of her maid-pale peace,
To ſcarlet indignation and bedew
Her paﬅors graﬀe with faithfull Engliſh bloud.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: The King of heauen forbid: our Lo: the king
Should ſo with ciuill and vnciuill armes,
be ruſht vpon. Thy thriſe noble Coſen,
Harry Bullingbrooke doth humbly kiﬀe thy hand,
And by the honourable tombe he ſweares,
That ﬅands vpon your roiall grandﬁres bones,
And by the roialties of both your blouds,
Currents that ſpring from one moﬅ gratious head,
And by the buried hand of warlike Gaunt,
And by the worth and honor of himſelfe,
Compriﬁng all that may be ſworne or ſaid,
His comming hither hath no further ſcope,
Then for his lineall roialties, and to beg
Infranchiſement immediate on his knees,
Which on thy roiall partie granted once,
His glittering armes he will commend to ruﬅ,
His barbed ﬅeeds to ﬅables, and his hart
To faithfull ſeruice of your Maieﬅy.
This ſweares he, as he is princeﬀe iuﬅ,
And as I am a gentleman I credit him.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Northumberland, ſay thus, the King returnes,
His noble Coſen is right welcome hither,
And all the number of his faire demaunds,
Shall be accompliſht without contradiƈtion,
With all the gratious vtterance thou haﬅ,
Speake to his gentle hearing kind commends.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: We do debaſe our ſelues, Coſen do we not,
To looke ſo poorely, and to ſpeake ſo faire?
Shall we call backe Northumberland, and ſend
Defiance to the traitor and ſo die?

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: No good my Lo: lets fight with gentle words,
Till time lend friends, and friends their helpfull ſwords.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Oh God oh God that ere this tong of mine
That laid the ſentence of dread baniſhment
On yon prowde man ſhould take it off againe
With words of ſooth! Oh that I were as great
As is my griefe, or leﬀer than my name!
Or that I could forget what I haue beene!
Or not remember what I muﬅ be now!
Swellﬅ thou (prowd heart) Ile giue thee ſcope to beate,
Since foes haue ſcope to beate both thee and me.

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: Northumberland comes backe from Bullingbrooke

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: What muﬅ the King do now? muﬅ he ſubmit?
The King ſhall do it: muﬅ he be depoſde?
The king ſhall be contented: muﬅ he looſe
The name of a King? a Gods name let it go:
Ile giue my iewels for a ſet of Beades:
My gorgeous pallace for a hermitage:
My gay apparel for an almeſmans gowne:
My figurde goblets for a diſh of wood:
My ſcepter for a Palmers walking ﬅaffe:
My ſubieƈts for a paire of carued Saintes,
And my large kingdome for a little graue,
A little little graue, an obſcure graue,
Or Ile be buried in the Kings hie way,
Some way of common trade, where ſubieƈts feete
May hourely trample on their ſoueraignes head;
For on my heart they treade now whilﬅ I liue:
And buried once, why not vpon my head?
Aumerle thou weepeﬅ (my tender-hearted cooﬁn)
Weele make fowle weather with deſpiſed teares;
Our ﬁghs and they ſhall lodge the ſummer corne,
And make a dearth in this reoulting land:
Or ſhall we play the wantons with our woes,
And make ſome pretty match with ſheading teares,
As thus to drop them ﬅill vpon one place,
Till they haue fretted vs a paire of graues
Within the earth, and therein laide; their lies
Two kinſmen digd their graues with weeping eies:
Would not this ill do well? well well I ſee,
I talke but idlely, and you laugh at me.
Moﬅ mightie Prince my Lord Northumberland,
What ſaies king Bullingbrooke, will his maieﬅie
Giue Richard leaue to liue till Richard dye,
You make a leg and Bullingbroke ſaies I.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: My Lord, in the baſe court he doth attend,
To ſpeake with you, may it pleaſe you to come downe.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Downe, downe I come, like gliﬅring Phaeton:
Wanting the manage of vnrulie Iades.
In the baſe court, baſe court where Kinges growe baſe,
To come at traitors calls, and do them grace,
In the baſe court come downe: downe court, downe King,
For nightowles ſhreeke where mounting larkes ſhould ﬁng.

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: What ſaies his maeieﬅie?

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Sorrowe and greife of hart,
Makes him ſpeake fondly like a frantike man,
Yet he is come.

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: Stand all apart,
And ſhew faire dutie to his Maieﬅie:
My gratious Lord.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: faire cooſen, you debaſe your princely knee,
To make the baſe earth proud with kiﬃng it:
Me rather had my hart might feele your loue,
Then my vnpleaſed eie ſee your curteﬁe:
Vp cooſen vp, your hart is vp I knowe,
Thus high at leaﬅ, although your knee be lowe.

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: My gratious Lord, I come but for mine owne.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Your owne is yours, and I am yours and all.

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: So farre be mine my moﬅ redoubted Lord,
As my true ſeruice ſhall deſerue your loue.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Well you deſerue: they well deſerue to haue,
That know the ﬅrong’ﬅ and ſureﬅ way to get,
Vncle giue me your handes, nay drie your eies,
Teares ſhew their loue, but want their remedies.
Cooſen I am to yong to be your Father,
Though you are old enough to be my heire,
What you will haue, Ile giue, and willing to,
For doe we muﬅ, what force will haue vs doe:
Set on towards London, Coſen is it ſo?

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: Yea my good Lord:

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Then I muﬅ not ſay no.

sceneref.stagedir: Enter the Queene with her attendants

speech.speaker: Quee.
speech.line: What ſport ſhall we deuiſe here in this garden,
To driue away the heauy thought of care?

speech.speaker: Lady
speech.line: Madame weele play at bowles.

speech.speaker: Quee.
speech.line: Twil make me thinke the world is full of rubs,
And that my fortune runs againﬅ the bias.

speech.speaker: Lady
speech.line: Madame weele daunce.

speech.speaker: Quee.
speech.line: My legs can keepe no meaſure in delight,
When my poore hart no meaſure keepes in griefe:
Therfore no dauncing girle, ſome other ſport,

speech.speaker: Lady
speech.line: Madam weele tell tales.

speech.speaker: Quee.
speech.line: Of ſorrow or of griefe.

speech.speaker: Lady.
speech.line: Of either Madame.

speech.speaker: Quee.
speech.line: Of neither girle:
For if of ioy, being altogither wanting,
It doth remember me the more of ſorrow:
Or if of griefe, being altogither bad,
It adds more ſorrow to my want of ioy:
For what I haue I need not to repeate,
And what I want it bootes not to complaine.

speech.speaker: Lady
speech.line: Madame ile ﬁng.

speech.speaker: Quee.
speech.line: Tis well that thou haﬅ cauſe,
But thou ſhouldﬅ pleaſe me better, wouldﬅ thou weepe.

speech.speaker: Lady.
speech.line: I could weepe; Madame would it doe you good?

speech.speaker: Quee.
speech.line: And I could ﬁng would weeping doe me good,
And neuer borrow any teare of thee.
But ﬅay, here come the gardeners,
Lets ﬅep into the ſhadow of theſe trees,
My wretchednes vnto a row of pines,
They will talke of ﬅate for euery one doth ſo,
Againﬅ a change woe is fore-runne with woe.

speech.speaker: Gard.
speech.line: Go bind thou vp yong dangling Aphricokes,
Which like vnruly children make their ﬁre,
Stoope with oppreſsion of their prodigall weight,
Giue ſome ſupportance to the bending twigs,
Go thou, and like an executioner
Cut off the heads of two faﬅ growing ſpraies,
That looke too loftie in our common-wealth,
All muﬅ be euen in our gouernement.
You thus employed, I will goe roote away
The noyſome weedes which without profit ſucke
The ſoiles fertilitie from wholſome flowers.

speech.speaker: Man.
speech.line: Why ſhould we in the compas of a pale,
Keepe law and forme, and due proportion,
Shewing as in a modle our firme eﬅate,
When our ſea-walled garden the whole land
Is full of weedes, her faireﬅ flowers choakt vp,
Her fruit trees all vnprunde, her hedges ruinde,
Her knots diſordered, and her holſome hearbs
Swarming with caterpillers.

speech.speaker: Gard.
speech.line: Hold thy peace,
He that htah ſuffered this diſordered ſpring,
Hath now himſelfe met with the fall of leafe:
The weedes which his broad ſpreading leaues did ſhelter,
That ſeemde in eating him to hold him vp,
Are pluckt vp roote and all by Bullingbrooke,
I meane the Earle of Wiltſhire, Buſhie, Greene,

speech.speaker: Man.
speech.line: What are they dead?

speech.speaker: Gard.
speech.line: They are.
And Bullingbrooke hath ceaſde the waﬅefull king,
Oh what pitie is it that he had not ſo trimde,
And dreﬅ his land as we this garden at time of yeare
Do wound the barke, the skinne of our fruit trees,
Leﬅ being ouer prowd in ſap and bloud,
With too much riches it confound it ſelfe
Had he done ſo to great and growing men,
They might haue liude to beare, and he to taﬅe
Their fruits of duety: ſuperfluous branches
We loppe away, that bearing boughes may liue:
Had he done ſo, himſelfe had borne the crowne,
Which waﬅe of idle houres hath quite throwne downe.

speech.speaker: Man.
speech.line: What, thinke you the King ſhall be depoſed?

speech.speaker: Gard.
speech.line: Depreﬅ he is already, and depoſde
Tis doubt he will be. Letters came laﬅ night
To a deare friend of the good Duke of Yorkes,
That tell blacke tidings.

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: Oh I am preﬅ to death through want of ſpeaking
Thou old Adams likeneﬀe ſet to dreﬀe this garden,
How dares thy harſh rude tong ſound this vnpleaﬁng news?
What Eue? what ſerpent hath ſuggeﬅed thee
To make a ſecond fall of curſed man?
Why doﬅ thou ſay king Richard is depoſde?
Darﬅ thou thou little better thing than earth
Diuine his downefall? ſay, where, when, and how,
Canﬅ thou by this ill tidings ſpeake thou wretch?

speech.speaker: Gard.
speech.line: Pardon me Madam, little ioy haue I
To breathe this newes, yet what I ſay is true:
King Richard he is in the mightie hold
Of Bullingbrooke: their fortunes both are weyde
In your Lo. ſcale is nothing but himſelfe,
And ſome few vanities that make him light:
But in the ballance of great Bullingbrooke,
Beﬁdes himſelfe are all the Engliſh peeres,
And with that oddes he weighs King Richard downe;
Poﬅ you to London and you will find it ſo,
I ſpeake no more then euery one doth know.

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: Nimble Miſchance that arte ſo light of foote,
Doth not thy embaﬀage belong to me,
And am I laﬅ that knowes it? Oh thou thinkeﬅ
To ſerue me laﬅ that I may longeﬅ keepe
Thy ſorrow in my breaﬅ: come Ladies go
To meete at London Londons king in wo.
What, was I borne to this that my ſad looke
Should grace the triumph of great Bullingbrooke?
Gardner for telling me theſe newes of wo,
Pray God the plants thou graftﬅ may neuer grow.

speech.speaker: Gard.
speech.line: Poore Queene, ſo that thy ﬅate might be no worſe,
I would my Skill were ſubieƈt to thy curſe:
Here did ſhe fall a teare, here in this place
Ile ſet a banke of Rew ſowre hearb of grace,
Rew euen for ruth heere ſhortly ſhall be ſeene,
In the remembrance of a weeping Queene.

sceneref.stagedir: Enter Bullingbrooke with the Lords to parliament.

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: Call forth Bagot.
Now Bagot, freely ſpeake thy mind,
What thou doeﬅ know of noble Glouceﬅers death,
Who wrought it with the King, and who performde
The bloudy office of his timeles end.

speech.speaker: Bagot
speech.line: Then ſet before my face the Lord Aumerle.

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: Couﬁn, ﬅand foorth, and looke vpon that man.

speech.speaker: Bagot
speech.line: My Lord Aumerle, I know your daring tong
Scornes to vnſay what once it hath deliuered.
In that dead time when Gloceﬅers death was plotted
I heard you ſay, Is not my arme of length,
That reacheth from the reﬅful Engliſh court,
As farre as Callice to mine vncles head?
Amongﬅ much other talke that very time
I heard you ſay, that you had rather refuſe
The offer of an hundred thouſand crownes,
Then Bullingbrookes returne to England, adding withall,
How bleﬅ this land would be in this your coﬁns death.

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: Princes and noble Lords,
What anſwer ſhall I make to this baſe man?
Shall I ſo much diſhonour my faire ﬅarres
On equall termes to giue them chaﬅicement?
Either I muﬅ, or haue mine honour ſoild
With the attainder of his ﬂaunderous lippes,
There is my gage, the manual ſeale of death,
That markes thee out for hell, I ſay thou lieﬅ,
And wil maintaine what thou haﬅ ſaid is falſe
In thy heart bloud, though being all too baſe
To ﬅaine the temper of my knightly ſword.

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: Bagot, forbeare, thou ſhalt not take it vp.

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: Excepting one, I would he were the beﬅ
In all this preſence that hath moude me ſo.

speech.speaker: Fitz.
speech.line: If that thy valure ﬅand on ﬁmpathie,
There is my gage Aumerle, in gage to thine;
By that faire Sunne which ſhews me where thou ﬅandﬅ,
I heard thee ſay, and vauntingly thou ſakﬅ it,
That thou wert cauſe of noble Glouceﬅers death.
If thou denieﬅ it twenty times, thou lieﬅ,
And I will turne thy falſhoode to thy heart,
Where it was forged with my rapiers point.

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: Thou darﬅ not (coward) liue to ſee that day.

speech.speaker: Fitz.
speech.line: Now by my ſoule, I would it were this houre.

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: Fitzwaters, thou art damnd to hell for this.

speech.speaker: L. Per.
speech.line: Aumerle, thou lieﬅ, his honour is as true
In this appeale as thou art all vniuﬅ,
And that thou art ſo, there I throwe my gage,
To prooue it on thee to the extreameﬅ point
Of mortall breathing, ceaze it if thou darﬅ.

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: And if I do not, may my hands rot off,
And neuer brandiſh more reuengefull ﬅeele
Ouer the glittering helmet of my foe.

speech.speaker: Another L.
speech.line: I taske the earth to the like (forſworne Aumerle)
And ſpurre thee on with full as many lies
As it may be hollowed in thy treacherous eare
From ﬁnne to ﬁnne: there is my honors pawne
Ingage it to the triall if thou dareﬅ.

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: Who ſets me elſe? by heauen Ile throwe at all,
I haue a thouſand ſpirites in one breaﬅ,
To anſwer twenty thouſand ſuch as you.

speech.speaker: Sur.
speech.line: My lord Fitzwater, I do remember well
The very time (Aumerle) and you did talke.

speech.speaker: Fitz.
speech.line: Tis very true you were in preſence then,
And you can witnes with me this is true.

speech.speaker: Sur.
speech.line: As falſe, by heauen, as heauen it ſelfe is true.

speech.speaker: Fitz.
speech.line: Surrie thou lieﬅ.

speech.speaker: Sur.
speech.line: Diſhonorable boy, that lie ſhall lie ſo heauie on my ſword,
That it ſhall render vengeance and reuenge,
Till thou the lie-giuer, and that lie do lie,
In earth as quiet as thy fathers ſcull.
In proofe whereof there is my honours pawne,
Ingage it to the triall if thou darﬅ.

speech.speaker: Fitz.
speech.line: How fondly doeﬅ thou ſpurre a forward horſe!
If I dare eate, or drinke, or breathe, or liue,
I dare meet Surry in a wildernes,
And ſpit vpon him whilﬅ I ſay, he lies,
And lies, and lies: there is bond of faith,
To tie thee to my ﬅrong correƈtion:
As I intende to thriue in this new world,
Aumerle is guiltie of my true appeale.
Beﬁdes I heard the baniſhed Norffolke ſay,
That thou Aumerle didﬅ ſend two of thy men,
To execute the noble Duke at Callice.

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: Some honeﬅ Chriﬅian truﬅ me with a gage,
That Norffolke lies, heere do I throwe downe this,
If he may be repeald to trie his honour.

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: Theſe differences ſhall all reﬅ vnder gage,
Till Norffolke be repeald, repeald he ſhallbe,
And though mine enimie, reﬅord againe
To all his landes and ﬁgnories: when he is returnd,
Againﬅ Aumerle we will inforce his triall.

speech.speaker: Carl.
speech.line: That honourable day ſhall neuer be ſeene,
Manie a time hath baniſht Norffolke fought,
For Ieſu Chriﬅ in glorious Chriﬅian feild,
Streaming the enﬁgne of the Chriﬅian Croﬀe,
Againﬅ blacke Pagans, Turkes, and Saracens,
And toild with workes of warre, retird him ſelfe
To Italie, and there at Venice gaue
His bodie to that pleaſant Countries earth,
And his pure ſoule vnto his Captaine Chriﬅ,
Vnder whoſe coulours he had fought ſo long.

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: Why B. is Norffolke dead?

speech.speaker: Carl.
speech.line: As ſurely as I liue my Lord.

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: Sweet peace conduƈt his ſweete ſoule to the boſome,
Of good olde Abraham: Lords Appellants,
Your differences ſhall all reﬅ vnder gage,
Till we aſsigne you to your daies of triall.

speech.speaker: Yorke
speech.line: Great Duke of Lancaﬅer I come to thee,
From plume-pluckt Richard, who with willing ſoule,
Adopts the heire, and his high ſcepter yeeldes,
To the poﬀeſsion of thy royall hand:
Aſcend his throne, deſcending now from him,
And long liue Henry fourth of that name.

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: In Gods name Ile aſcend the regall throne.

speech.speaker: Car.
speech.line: Mary God forbid.
Worﬅ in this royall preſence may I ſpeake,
Yet beﬅ beſeeming me to ſpeake the truth,
Would God that any in this noble preſence,
Were enough noble to be vpright iudge
Of noble Richard. Then true nobleﬀe would
Learne him forbearance from ſo foule a wrong,
What ſubieƈt can giue ſentence on his King:
And who ﬁts here that is not Richards ſubieƈt?
Theeues are not iudgd but they are by to heare,
Although apparant guilt be ſeene in them,
And ſhall the figure of Gods Maieﬅy,
His Captaine, ﬅeward, deputy, eleƈt,
Annointed, crowned, planted, many yeares
Be iudgd by ſubieƈt and inferiour breath,
And he himſelfe not preſent? Oh forfend it God,
That in a Chriﬅian climate ſoules refinde,
Should ſhew ſo heinous blacke obſceene a deed
I ſpeake to ſubieƈts and a ſubieƈt ſpeakes,
Stird vp by God thus boldly for his King,
My Lord of Hereford here whom you call King,
Is a foule traitour to proud Herefords King,
And if you crowne him let me propheﬁe,
The bloud of Engliſh ſhall manure the ground,
And future ages groane for this foule aƈt,
Peace ſhall go ﬂeepe with turkes and infidels,
And in this ſeate of peace, tumultuous warres,
Shall kin with kin, and kinde with kind confound:
Diſorder, horror, feare and mutiny,
Shall heere inhabit, and this land be cald,
The field of Golgotha and dead mens ſculs.
Oh if yon raiſe this houſe againﬅ this houſe,
It will the wofulleﬅ diuiﬁon proue,
That euer fell vpon this curſed earth:
Preuent it, reﬁﬅ it, let it not be ſo,
Leﬅ child, childs children, crie againﬅ you wo.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Well haue you argued ﬁr, and for your paines,
Of Capitall treaſon, we arreﬅ you heere:
My Lord of Weﬅminﬅer, be it your charge,
To keepe him ſafely till his day of triall.

speech.speaker: Bull.
speech.line: Let it be ſo, and loe on wedneſday next,
We ſolemnely proclaime our Coronation,
Lords be ready all.

speech.speaker: Abbot.
speech.line: A wofull Pageant haue we heere beheld.

speech.speaker: Car.
speech.line: The woe’s to come, the children yet vnborne,
Shall feele this day as ſharp to them as thorne.

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: You holy Clergy men, is there no plot,
To ridde the realme of this pernitious blot?

speech.speaker: Abbot.
speech.line: My Lo. before I freely ſpeake my mind heerein,
You ſhall not onely take the Sacrament,
To burie mine intents, but alſo to effeƈt,
What euer I ſhall happen to deuiſe:
I ſee your browes are full of diſcontent,
Your harts of ſorrow, and your eies of teares:
Come home with me to ſupper, Ile lay a plot,
Shall ſhew vs all a merrie daie.

sceneref.stagedir: Enter the Queene with her attendants.

speech.speaker: Quee.
speech.line: This way the King will come, this is the way,
To Iulius Cæſars ill ereƈted Tower,
To wohſe flint boſome, my condemned Lord,
Is doomde a priſoner by proud Bullingbrooke,
Heere let vs reﬅ, if this rebellious earth,
Haue any reﬅing for her true Kings Queene.
But ſoft, but ſee, or rather doe not ſee,
My faire Roſe wither, yet looke vp, behold,
That you in pittie may diﬀolue to deaw,
And waſh him freſh againe with true loue teares.
Ah thou the modle where olde Troy did ﬅand!
Thou mappe of honour, thou King Richards tombe,
And not King Richard: thou moﬅ beauteous Inne,
Why ſhould hard fauourd greife be lodged in thee,
When triumph is become an alehouſe gueﬅ?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: ioyne not with greife faire woman, doe not ſo,
To make my end too ſudden, learne good ſoule,
To thinke our former ﬅate a happie dreame,
From which awakt the trueth of what we are
Shewes vs but this: I am ſworne brother (ſweet)
To grim neceﬃtie, and he and I,
Will keepe a league till death. Hie thee to Fraunce,
And cloiﬅer thee in ſome religious houſe,
Our holy liues muﬅ win a new worlds crowne,
VVhich our prophane houres heere haue throwne downe.

speech.speaker: Quee.
speech.line: what is my Richard both in ſhape and minde
Transformd and weakned? hath Bullingbrooke,
Depoſde thine intelleƈt? hath he been in thy hart?
The Lyon dying thruﬅeth foorth his pawe,
And woundes the earth if nothing elſe with rage,
To be ore-powr’d, and wilt thou pupill-like
Take the correƈtion, mildly kiﬀe the rod,
And fawne on Rage with baſe humilitie,
VVhich art a Lion and the king of beaﬅs.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: a King of beaﬅs indeed, if aught but beaﬅ,
I had been ﬅill a happie King of men.
Good (ſometimes Queene) prepare thee hence for France,
Thinke I am dead, and that euen here thou takeﬅ
As from my death bed thy laﬅ liuing leaue;
In winters tedious nights ﬁt by the fire,
with good old folkes, and let them tell the tales,
Of woefull ages long agoe betidde:
And ere thou bid good night to quite their griefes,
Tell thou the lamentable tale of me,
And ſend the hearers weeping to their beds:
For why, the ſenﬂeﬀe brands will ﬁmpathize
The heauy accent of thy moouing tong,
And in compaſsion weepe the fire out,
And ſome wil mourne in aſhes, ſome cole blacke,
For the depoﬁng of a rightfull King.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: My Lord, the minde of Bullingbrooke is changde,
You muﬅ to Pomfret, not vnto the Tower.
And Madam, there is order tane for you,
With al ſwift ſpeede you muﬅ away to France.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Northumberland, thou ladder wherewithall
The mounting Bullingbrooke aſcends my throne,
The time ſhall not be many houres of age
More than it is, ere foule ﬁnne gathering head
Shall breake into corruption, thou ſhalt thinke,
Though he diuide the realme and giue thee halfe,
It is too little helping him to all.
He ſhall thinke that thou which knoweﬅ the way
To plant vnrightfull kings, wilt know againe,
Being nere ſo little vrgde another way,
To plucke him headlong from the vſurped throne:
The loue of wicked men conuerts to feare,
That feare to hate, and hate turnes one or both
To worthy daunger and deſerued death.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: My guilt be on my head, and there an end:
Take leaue and part, for you muﬅ part forthwith.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Doubly diuorﬅ (bad men) you violate
A two-fold marriage twixt my crowne and me,
And then betwixt me and my married wife.
Let me vnkiﬀe the oathe twixt thee and me:
And yet not ſo, for with a kiﬀe twas made.
Part vs Northumberland, I towardes the north,
Where ſhiuering cold and ﬁckeneﬀe pines the clime:
My wife to Fraunce, from whence ſet forth in pomp
She came adorned hither like ſweete Maie,
Sent backe like Hollowmas or ſhortﬅ of day.

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: And muﬅ we be deuided? muﬅ we part?

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: I hand from hand (my loue) and heart from heart.

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: Baniſh vs both, and ſend the King with me.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: That were ſome loue, but litle pollicie.

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: Then whither he goes, thither let me go.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: So two togither weeping make one woe,
Weepe thou for me in Fraunce, I for thee heere,
Better far off than neere be nere the neare,
Go count thy way with ﬁghes, I mine with groanes.

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: So longeﬅ way ſhall haue the longeﬅ moanes.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: T wiſe for one ﬅep Ile grone the way being ſhort
And peece the way out with a heauy heart.
Come come in wooing ſorrow lets be briefe,
Since wedding it, there is ſuch length in griefe;
One kiﬀe ſhall ﬅop our mouths, and dumbly part,
Thus giue I mine, and thus take I thy heart.

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: Giue me mine owne againe, twere no good part
To take on me to keepe, and kill thy heart:
So now I haue mine owne againe, be gone,
That I may ﬅriue to kill it with a groane.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: We make woe wanton with this fond delay,
Once more adue, the reﬅ let ſorrow ſay.

sceneref.stagedir: Enter Duke of Yorke and the Dutcheße.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: My Lord, you told me you would tell the reﬅ,
When weeping made you breake the ﬅorie of
Of our two couﬁns comming into London.

speech.speaker: Yorke
speech.line: Where did I leaue?

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: At that ſad ﬅop my Lord,
Where rude miſgouerned hands from windowes tops,
Threw duﬅ and rubbiſh on king Richards head.

speech.speaker: Yorke
speech.line: Then (as I ſaid) the Duke great Bullingbrooke
Mounted vpon a hote and fierie ﬅeede,
Which his aſpiring rider ſeemd to know,
With ﬂow, but ﬅately paſe kept on his courſe,
Whilﬅ all tongues cried, God ſaue the Bullingbrooke,
You would haue thought the very windows ſpake:
So many greedy lookes of yong and old
Through caſements darted their deﬁring eies
Vpon his viſage, and that all the walles
With painted imagery had ſaid at once,
Ieſu preſerue the welcome Bullingbrooke,
Whilﬅ he from the one ﬁde to the other turning
Bare-headed, lower than his prowd ﬅeedes necke
Beſpake them thus; I thanke you countrymen:
And thus ﬅill doing, thus he paﬀt along.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Alac poore Richard, where rode he the whilﬅ?

speech.speaker: Yorke
speech.line: As in a Theater the eies of men,
After a well-graced Aƈtor leaues the ﬅage,
Are ydly bent on him that enters next,
Thinking his prattle to be tedious;
Euen ſo, or with much more contempt mens eies
Did ſcowle on gentle Ric. no man cried, God ſaue him,
No ioyfull tongue gaue him his welcome home,
But duﬅ was throwen vpon his ſacred head:
Which with ſuch gentle ſorrow he ſhooke off,
His face ﬅill combating with teares and ſmiles,
The badges of his griefe and patience,
That had not God for ſome ﬅrong purpoſe ﬅeeld
The hearts of men, they muﬅ perforce haue melted,
And Barbariſme it ſelfe haue pittied him:
But heauen hath a hand in theſe euents,
To whoſe high will we bound our calme contents.
To Bullingbrooke are we ſworne ſubieƈts now,
Whoſe ﬅate and honour I for ay allow.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Here comes my ſonne Aumerle.

speech.speaker: Yorke
speech.line: Aumerle that was,
But that is loﬅ, for being Richards friend:
And Madam, you muﬅ call him Rutland now:
I am in parleament pledge for his truth
And laﬅing fealtie to the new made king.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Welcome my ſonne, who are the violets now
That ﬅrew the greene lap of the new come ſpring.

speech.speaker: Au.
speech.line: Madam, I know not, nor I greatly care not,
God knowes I had as leife be none as one.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: Well, beare you wel in this new ſpring of time,
Leﬅ you be cropt before you come to prime.
What newes from Oxford, do theſe iuﬅs & triumphs hold?

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: For aught I know (my Lord) they do.

speech.speaker: Yorke
speech.line: you will be there I know.

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: If God preuent not, I purpoſe ſo.

speech.speaker: Yorke
speech.line: What ſeale is that that hangs without thy boſome?
yea, lookﬅ thou pale? let me ſee the writing,

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: My Lord, tis nothing.

speech.speaker: Yorke
speech.line: No matter then who ſee it,
I will be ſatisfied, let me ſee the writing.

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: I do beſeech your grace to pardon me,
It is a matter of ſmall conſequence,
Which for ſome reaſons I would not haue ſeene.

speech.speaker: Yorke
speech.line: Which for ſome reaſons ﬁr I meane to ſee.
I feare I feare.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: What ſhould you feare?
Tis nothing but ſome band that he is entred into
For gay apparell gainﬅ the triumph day.

speech.speaker: Yorke
speech.line: Bound to himſelfe; what doth he with a bond
That he is bound to. Wife, thou art a foole:
Boy, let me ſee the writing.

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: I do beſeech you pardon me, I may not ſhew it.

speech.speaker: Yorke
speech.line: I will be ſatisfied, let me ſee it I ſay:

sceneref.stagedir: He pluckes it out of his boſome and reades it:

speech.speaker: Yorke
speech.line: Treaſon, foule treaſon, villaine, traitor, ﬂaue,

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: What is the matter my lord?

speech.speaker: Yorke
speech.line: Ho, who is within there? ſaddle my horſe,
God for his mercy! what treachery is here?

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Why what is it my Lord?

speech.speaker: Yorke
speech.line: Giue me my bootes I ſay, ſaddle my horſe,
Now by mine honour, by my life, by my troth
I will appeach the villaine.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: What is the matter?

speech.speaker: Yorke
speech.line: Peace fooliſh woman.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: I wil not peace, what is the matter Aumerle?

speech.speaker: Au.
speech.line: Good mother be content, it is no more
Then my poore life muﬅ anſwere.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Thy life anſwere?

speech.speaker: yor.
speech.line: Bring me my bootes, I will vnto the King.

sceneref.stagedir: His man enters with his bootes.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Strike him Aumerle, poore boy thou art amazd,
Hence vilaine neuer more come in my ﬁght.

speech.speaker: Yor.
speech.line: Giue me my bootes I ſay.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Why Yorke what wilt thou doe?
Wilt thou not hide the treſpaﬀe of thine owne?
Haue we more ſons? or are we like to haue?
Is not my teeming date drunke vp with time?
And wilt thou plucke my faire ſonne from mine age?
And rob me of a happie mothers name,
Is he not like the? is he not thine owne?

speech.speaker: Yor.
speech.line: Thou fond mad woman,
Wilt thou conceale this darke conſpiracie?
A doozen of them here haue tane the ſacrament,
And interchaungeably ſet downe there hands,
To kill the king at Oxford.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: He ſhal be none, weele keepe him heere,
Then what is that to him?

speech.speaker: Yor.
speech.line: Away fond woman, were he twentie times my ſonne,
I would appeach him.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Hadﬅ thou groand for him as I haue done,
Thou wouldﬅ bee more pittifull.
But nowe I knowe rhy minde, thou doeﬅ ſuſpeƈt
That I haue been diﬂoiall to thy bed,
And that he is a baﬅard, not thy ſonne:
Sweete Yorke, ſweete husband, be not of that mind,
He is as like thee as a man may be,
Not like to me, or any of my kinne,
And yet I loue him.

speech.speaker: Yor.
speech.line: Make way vnrulie woman.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: After Aumerle: mount thee vpon his horſe,
Spur, poﬅ, and get before him to the King,
And beg thy pardon ere he do accuſe thee,
Ile not be long behind, though I be old,
I doubt not but to ride as faﬅ as Yorke,
An neuer will I riſe vp from the ground,
Till Bullingbroke haue pardoned thee: away, be gone.

sceneref.stagedir: Enter the King with his nobles.

speech.speaker: King H.
speech.line: Can no man tell me of my vnthriftie ſonne?
Tis full three moneths ﬁnce I did ſee him laﬅ,
If any plague hang ouer vs tis he:
I would to God my Lordes he might be found:
Inquire at London, mongﬅ the Tauernes there,
For there (they ſay) he daylie doth frequent,
With vnreﬅrained looſe companions,
Euen ſuch (they ſay) as ﬅand in narrow lanes,
And beate our watch, and rob our paﬀengers,
Which he yong wanton and effeminate boy,
Takes on the point of honour to ſupport ſo diﬀolute a crew.

speech.speaker: H. Percie.
speech.line: My Lord, ſome two dayes ﬁnce I ſaw the prince,
And tould him of thoſe triumphes helde at Oxford.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: And what ſaid the gallant?

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: His anſwer was, he would vnto the ﬅews,
And from the commonﬅ creature plucke a gloue,
And weare it as a fauour, and with that,
He would vnhorſe the luﬅieﬅ Challenger.

speech.speaker: King H.
speech.line: As diﬀolute as deſperat, yet through both,
I ſee ſome ſparkes of better hope, which elder yeares,
May happily bring foorth. But who comes heere?

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: Where is the King?

speech.speaker: King H.
speech.line: What meanes our coſen, that he ﬅares and lookes ſo wildly.

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: God ſaue your grace, I doe beſeech your Maieﬅie,
To haue ſome conference with your grace alone.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Withdrawe your ſelues, and leaue vs here alone.
What is the matter with our coſen nowe?

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: For euer may my knees growe to the earth,
My tongue, cleaue to my rooffe within my mouth,
Vnleﬀe a pardon ere I riſe or ſpeake.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Intended, or committed, was this fault?
If on the firﬅ, how heynous ere it be
To win thy after loue, I pardon thee.

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: Then giue me leaue that May turne the key,
That no man enter till my tale be done.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Haue thy deﬁre.

sceneref.stagedir: The Duke of Yorke knokes at the doore and crieth.

speech.speaker: Yor.
speech.line: My liege beware, looke to thy ſelfe,
Thou haﬅ a Traitor in thy preſence there.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Vilain Ile make thee ſafe.

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: Stay thy reuengefull hand, thou haﬅ no cauſe to feare

speech.speaker: York.
speech.line: Open the dore, ſecure foole, hardie King,
Shall I for loue ſpeake treaſon to thy face,
Open the dore, or I will breake it open.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: What is the matter vncle, ſpeake, recouer breath,
Tell vs, how neare is daunger,
That wee may arme vs to encounter it?

speech.speaker: Yor.
speech.line: Peruſe this writtng heere, and thou ſhalt know,
The treaſon that my haﬅe forbids me ſhew.

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: remember as thou readﬅ, thy promiſe paﬅ,
I do repent me, reade not my name there,
My hart is not confederate with my hand.

speech.speaker: Yor.
speech.line: It was (vilaine) ere thy hand did ſet it downe.
I tore it from the traitors boſome (King,)
Feare, and not loue, begets his penitence:
Forget to pittie him, leﬅ thy pittie proue,
A Serpent that will ﬅing thee to the hart.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: O heynous, ﬅrong, and bould conſpiracy;
O loyall Father, of a treacherous Sonne,
Thou ſheere immaculate and ﬁluer Fountaine,
From whence this ﬅreame, through muddy paﬀages,
Hath held his current, and defild himſelfe,
Thy ouerflow of good, conuerts to bad:
And thy aboundant goodnes, ſhall excuſe,
This deadly blot in thy digreﬃng ſonne.

speech.speaker: Yor.
speech.line: So ſhall my vertue, be his vices baude,
An he ſhall ſpend mine honour, with his ſhame,
As thriftles ſonnes, their ſcraping Fathers gold:
Mine honour liues when his diſhonour dies,
Or my ſhamde life in his diſhonour lies,
Thou kilﬅ me in his life giuing him breath,
The traitor liues, the true man’s put to death.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: What ho, my Liege, for Gods ſake let me in.

speech.speaker: King H.
speech.line: What ſhril voice ſuppliant makes this eger crie?

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: A woman, and thy aunt (great king) tis I,
Speake with me, pitie me, open the doore,
A beggar begs that neuer begd before.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Our ſcene is altred from a ſerious thing,
And now changde to the Beggar and the King:
My dangerous couﬁn, let your mother in,
I know ſhe is come to pray for your foule ﬁnne.

speech.speaker: Yorke
speech.line: If thou do pardon whoſoeuer pray,
More ﬁnnes for this forgiuenes proſper may:
This feﬅred ioynt cut off, the reﬅ reﬅ ſound,
This let alone wil all the reﬅ confound.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Oh king, beleeue not this hard-hearted man,
Loue louing not it ſelfe, none other can.

speech.speaker: Yorke
speech.line: Thou frantike woman, what doﬅ thou make here?
Shall thy old dugs once more a traitor reare?

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Sweete Yorke be patient, heare me gentle Liege.

speech.speaker: King H
speech.line: Riſe vp good aunt.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Not yet I thee beſeech,
For euer wil I walke vpon my knees,
And neuer ſee day that the happy ſees,
Till thou giue ioy, vntil thou bid me ioy,
By pardoning Rutland my tranſgreſsing boy.

speech.speaker: Aum.
speech.line: Vnto my mothers prayers I bend my knee.

speech.speaker: yorke
speech.line: Againﬅ them both my true ioynts bended be,
Ill maiﬅ thou thriue if thou graunt any grace.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Pleades he in earneﬅ? looke vpon his face.
His eies do drop no teares, his prayers are in ieﬅ,
His words come from his mouth, ours from our breaﬅ,
He prayes but faintly, and would be denied,
We pray with heart and ſoule, and all beﬁde,
His weary ioynts would gladly riſe I know,
Our knees ﬅill kneele till to the ground they grow,
His prayers are full of falſe hypocriﬁe,
Ours of true zeale and deepe integritie,
Our prayers do outpray his, then let them haue
That mercy which true prayer ought to haue.

speech.speaker: yorke
speech.line: Good aunt ﬅand vp.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Nay, do not ſay, ﬅand vp;
Say Pardon firﬅ, and afterwards, ﬅand vp,
And if I were thy nurſe thy tong to teach,
Pardon ſhould be the firﬅ word of thy ſpeach:
I neuer longd to heare a word till now,
Say pardon King, let pitie teach thee how,
The word is ſhort, but not ſo ſhort as ſweete,
No word like pardon for Kings mouthes ſo meete.

speech.speaker: yorke
speech.line: Speake it in French, King ſay, Pardonne moy.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Doﬅ thou teach pardon pardon to deﬅroy?
Ah my ſower husband, my hard-hearted Lord!
That ſets the word it ſelfe againﬅ the word:
Speake pardon as tis currant in our land,
The chopping French we do not vnderﬅand,
Thine eie begins to ſpeake, ſet thy tongue there:
Or in thy piteous heart plant thou thine eare,
That hearing how our plaints and prayers do pierce,
Pitie may mooue thee pardon to rehearſe.

speech.speaker: King H.
speech.line: Good aunt ﬅand vp.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: I do not ſue to ﬅand.
Pardon is all the ſute I haue in hand.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: I pardon him as God ſhall pardon me.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: O happy vantage of a kneeling knee,
Yet am I ﬁcke for feare, ſpeake it againe,
Twice ſaying pardon doth not pardon twaine,
But makes one pardon ﬅrong.

speech.speaker: King H.
speech.line: I pardon him with al my heart.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: A god on earth thou art.

speech.speaker: King H.
speech.line: But for our truﬅy brother in law and the Abbot,
With all the reﬅ of that conſorted crew,
Deﬅruƈtion ﬅrait ſhal dog them at the heeles,
Good vncle, help to order ſeuerall powers,
To Oxford, or where ere theſe traitors are,
They ſhall not liue within this world I ſweare,
But I will haue them if I once know where.
Vncle farewell, and couﬁn adue,
Your mother well hath prayed, and prooue you true.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Come my olde ſonne, I pray God make thee new.

speech.speaker: Exton
speech.line: Didﬅ thou not marke the K. what words he ſpake?
Haue I no friend will rid me of this liuing feare?
Was it not ſo?

speech.speaker: Man
speech.line: Theſe were his very words.

speech.speaker: Exton
speech.line: Haue I no friend quoth he? he ſpake it twice.
And vrgde it twice togither, did he not?

speech.speaker: Man
speech.line: He did.

speech.speaker: Exton
speech.line: And ſpeaking it, he wiſhtly lookt on me,
As who ſhould ſay, I would thou wert the man,
That would diuorce this terrour from my heart,
Meaning the king at Pomfret. Come lets go,
I am the kings friend, and will rid his foe.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: I haue beene ﬅudying how I may compare
This priſon where I liue, vnto the world:
And for becauſe the world is populous,
And here is not a creature but my ſelfe,
I cannot do it: yet Ile hammer it out,
My braine Ile prooue, the female to my ſoule,
My ſoule the father, and theſe two beget
A generation of ﬅill-breeding thoughts:
And theſe ſame thoughts people this little world,
In humors like the people of this world:
For no thought is contented: the better ſort,
As thoughts of things diuine are intermixt
With ſcruples, and do ſet the word it ſelfe
Againﬅ the word, as thus: Come little ones, & then againe
It is as hard to come, as for a Cammell
To threed the poﬅerne of a ſmall needles eie:
Thoughts tending to ambition they do plot,
Vnlikely wonders: how theſe vaine weake nailes
May teare a paﬀage thorow the flinty ribs
Of this hard world my ragged priſon walles:
And for they cannot die in their owne pride,
Thoughts tending to content flatter themſelues,
That they are not the firﬅ of fortunes ﬂaues,
Nor ſhall not be the laﬅ like ſeely beggars,
Who ﬁtting in the ﬅockes refuge their ſhame,
That many haue, and others muﬅ ſet there.
And in this thought they find a kind of eaſe,
Bearing their owne misfortunes on the backe
Of ſuch as haue before indurde the like.
Thus play I in one perſon many people,
And none contented; ſometimes am I King,
Then treaſons make me wiſh my ſelfe a beggar,
And ſo I am: then cruſhing penurie
Perſwades me I was better when a king,
Then am I kingd againe, and by and by,
Thinke that I am vnkingd by Bullingbrooke,
And ﬅrait am nothing. But what ere I be,
Nor I, nor any man, that but man is,
With nothing ſhall be pleaſde, till he be eaſde,
With being nothing. Muﬁcke do I heare,
Ha ha keepe time, how ſowre ſweete Muﬁcke is
When time is broke, and no proportion kept,
So is it in the muﬁke of mens liues:
And here haue I the daintineﬀe of eare
To checke time broke in diſordered ﬅring:
But for the concord of my ﬅate and time,
Had not an eare to heare my true time broke,
I waﬅed time, and now doth time waﬅe me:
For now hath time made me his numbring clocke;
My thoughts are minutes, and with ﬁghes they iarre,
Their watches on vnto mine eyes the outward watch
Whereto my finger like a dialles poynt,
Is pointing ﬅill, in cleanﬁng them from teares.
Now ﬁr, the ſound that telles what houre it is,
Are clamorous groanes which ﬅrike vpon my hart,
Which is the bell, ſo ﬁghs, and teares, and grones,
Shew minutes, times, and houres: but my time,
Runnes poﬅing on in Bullingbrokes proud ioye,
While I ﬅand fooling heere his iacke of the clocke
This muﬁcke maddes me, let it ſound no more,
For though it haue holp mad men to their witts,
In me it ſeemes it will make wiſe men mad:
Yet bleﬃng on his hart that giues it me,
For tis aﬁgne of loue: and loue to Richard,
Is a ﬅrange brooch in this al-hating world.

sceneref.stagedir: Enter a groome of the ﬅable.

speech.speaker: Groome.
speech.line: Haile roiall Prince.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Thankes noble peare:
The cheapeﬅ of vs is ten grotes too deare.
What art thou, and how comeﬅ thou hither,
Where no man neuer comes, but that ſad dog,
That brings me foode to make miſfortune liue.

speech.speaker: Groome.
speech.line: I was a poore groome of thy ﬅable King,
When thou wert King: who trauailling towards Yorke,
With much adoe (at length) haue gotten leaue,
To looke vpon my ſometimes roiall maiﬅers face:
Oh how it ernd my hart when I beheld,
In London ﬅreetes, that Corronation day,
When Bullingbroke rode on Roane Barbarie,
That horſe, that thou ſo often haﬅ beﬅride,
That horſe, that I ſo carefully haue dreﬅ.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Rode he on Barbarie, tell me gentle freind,
How went he vnder him?

speech.speaker: Groom.
speech.line: So proudly as if he diſdaind the ground.

speech.speaker: Ric.
speech.line: So proud that Bullingbroke was on his backe:
That Iade hath eate bread from my royall hand,
This hand hath made him proud with clapping him:
Would he not ﬅumble, would he not fall downe
Since pride muﬅ haue a fal; and breake the necke,
Of that prond man, that did vſurpe his backe?
Forgiuenes horſe why do I raile on thee?
Since thou created to be awed by man,
Waﬅ borne to beare; I was not made a horſe,
And yet I beare a burthen like an aﬀe,
Spurrde, galld, and tirde by iauncing Bullingbrooke.

sceneref.stagedir: Enter one to Richard with meate.

speech.speaker: Keeper
speech.line: Fellow, giue place, heere is no longer ﬅay.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: If thou loue me, tis time thou wert away.

speech.speaker: Groome
speech.line: What my tong dares not, that my heart ſhal ſay

speech.speaker: Keeper
speech.line: My Lord, wilt pleaſe you to fall to?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Taﬅe of it firﬅ as thou art wont to do.

speech.speaker: Keeper
speech.line: My Lord I dare not, ﬁr Pierce of Exton,
Who lately came from the King commaunds the contrary.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: The diuell take Henry of Lancaﬅer, and thee,
Patience is ﬅale, and I am wearie of it.

speech.speaker: Keeper
speech.line: Help, help, help.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: How now, what meanes Death in this rude aﬀault?
Villaine, thy owne hand yeelds thy deaths inﬅrument,
Go thou and fill another roome in hell.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: That hand ſhall burne in neuer quenching fire,
That ﬅaggers thus my perſon: Exton, thy fierce hand
Hath with the kings bloud ﬅaind the kings owne land.
Mount mount my ſoule, thy ſeate is vp on high,
Whilﬅ my groﬀe fleſh ﬁnckes downeward here to die,

speech.speaker: Exton
speech.line: As full of valure as of royall bloud:
Both haue I ſpilld, Oh would the deede were good!
For now the diuell that told me I did well,
Saies that this deede is chronicled in hell:
This dead king to the liuing king Ile beare.
Take hence the reﬅ, and giue them buriall heere.

sceneref.stagedir: Enter Bullingbrooke with the duke of Yorke.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Kind vncle Yorke, the lateﬅ newes we heare,
Is, that the rebels haue conſumed with fire
Our towne of Ciceter in Glouceﬅerſhire,
But whether they be tane or ﬂaine, we heare not.
Welcome my Lord, what is the newes?

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Firﬅ to thy ſacred ﬅate wiſh I all happineﬀe,
The next newes is, I haue to London ſent
The heades of Oxford, Salisbury, Blunt and Kent,
The maner of their taking may appeare
At large diſcourſed in this paper heere.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: We thanke thee gentle Percie for thy paines,
And to thy woorth will adde right worthy gaines.

speech.speaker: Fitz.
speech.line: My Lord, I haue from Oxford ſent to London
The heads of Broccas, and ﬁr Benet Seely,
Two of the daungerous conſorted traitors,
That ſought at Oxford thy dire ouerthrow.

speech.speaker: king
speech.line: Thy paines Fitz. ſhall nor be forgot,
Right noble is thy merit well I wot.

speech.speaker: Percie
speech.line: The grand conſpirator Abbot of Weﬅminﬅer
With clog of conſcience and ſowre melancholy
Hath yeelded vp his body to the graue.
But here is Carleil liuing, to abide
Thy kingly doome, and ſentence of his pride.

speech.speaker: king
speech.line: Carleil, this is your doome;
Chooſe out ſome ſecret place, ſome reuerent roome
More than thou haﬅ, and with it ioy thy life:
So as thou liu’ﬅ in peace, die free from ﬅrife,
For though mine enemy thou haﬅ euer beene,
High ſparkes of honour in thee haue I ſeene.

speech.speaker: Exton
speech.line: Great King, within this coffin I preſent
Thy buried feare: herein all breathleﬀe lies
The mightieﬅ of thy greateﬅ enemies,
Richard of Burdeaux, by me hither brought.

speech.speaker: king
speech.line: Exton, I thanke thee not, for thou haﬅ wrought
A deed of ﬂaunder with thy fatall hand,
Vpon my head and all this famous Land.

speech.speaker: Exton.
speech.line: From your owne mouth my Lo. did I this deed.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: They loue not poiſon that do poiſon neede,
Nor do I thee; though I did wiſh him dead,
I hate the murtherer, loue him murthered:
The guilt of conſcience take thou for thy labor,
But neither my good word, nor Princely fauour;
With Cayne go wander through ſhades of night,
And neuer ſhew thy head by day nor light.
Lordes, I proteﬅ my ſoule is full of wo,
That bloud ſhould ſprincle me to make me grow:
Come mourne with me, for what I do lament,
And put on ſulleyn blacke incontinent,
Ile make a voiage to the holly lande,
To waſh this bloud off from my guiltie hand:
March ſadly after, grace my mournings heere,
In weeping after this vntimely Beere.
